Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0101 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0102 AIR FLOW SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0102: Air flow Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Power is supplied by the engine-ECU connector terminal AFSB to the air flow sensor connector terminal, and the air flow sensor connector terminal is earthed through the engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE.
  • The air flow sensor connector terminal outputs a sensor signal, which is input into the engine-ECU connector terminal AFSM.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The air flow sensor outputs pulse signal that varies in accordance with the intake air volume.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls EGR control, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The air flow sensor output voltage is 0.50 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The control is performed using the previous value.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed air flow sensor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in air flow sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU AFSB line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal AFSB and air flow sensor connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform resistance measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU AFSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal AFSB and air flow sensor connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSM
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0102 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0102 AIR FLOW SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N15>
Code No. P0102: Air flow Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0101: Air Flow Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N15> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The air flow sensor outputs pulse signal that varies in accordance with the intake air volume.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls EGR control, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The air flow sensor output voltage is 0.50 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The control is performed using the previous value.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed air flow sensor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in air flow sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine control relay connector terminal and air flow sensor connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform resistance measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU AFSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between engine control relay connector terminal and air flow sensor connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFS
  • Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0102 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0103 AIR FLOW SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0103: Air Flow Sensor Circuit High Input <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0102: Air flow Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The air flow sensor outputs pulse signal that varies in accordance with the intake air volume.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls EGR control, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The air flow sensor output voltage is 4.72 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The control is performed using the previous value.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed air flow sensor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in air flow sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU AFSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to Data List Reference Table ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0103 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0103 AIR FLOW SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT<4N15>
Code No. P0103: Air Flow Sensor Circuit High Input <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0101: Air Flow Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N15> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The air flow sensor outputs pulse signal that varies in accordance with the intake air volume.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls EGR control, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The air flow sensor output voltage is 4.72 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The control is performed using the previous value.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed air flow sensor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in air flow sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at air flow sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU AFSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to Data List Reference Table ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0103 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0106 MANIFOLD ABSOLUTE PRESSURE SENSOR RANGE/PERFORMANCE PROBLEM<4N14>
Code No. P0106: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the manifold absolute pressure sensor power terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal MAP5 and earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal MAPE from the manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal.
  • The sensor signal is inputted to the engine-ECU connector terminal MAP from the manifold absolute pressure sensor output terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The manifold absolute pressure sensor converts the manifold absolute pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
  • The following 3 conditions are formed:
    1. The engine cooling water temperature is from 80 to 115°C.
    2. The intake air temperature is from -5 to 80°C.
    3. The atmospheric pressure is from 76 to 120 kPa.
Judgement Criterion
  • When an idle state and an engine rotation speed of 2,000 r/min continue for 3 seconds, manifold absolute pressure are read and the difference between them goes under 800 Pa for 5 seconds.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed manifold absolute pressure sensor.
  • Manifold absolute pressure sensor circuit harness damage or loose connector contact.
  • EGR cooler clogged.
  • EGR pipe (A, B) clogged.
  • EGR cooler by-pass valve clogged.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
  • Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP5.
    • Check power supply line for damage.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAPE line and body earth.
OK: 0.5 V or less
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAPE.
    • Check earthing line for damage.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP line and body earth.
OK: The voltage should be 0.7 to 1.2 V. When the accelerator pedal is quickly depressed from the idling state, the voltage temporarily rises.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the manifold absolute pressure sensor.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check on clogged EGR cooler
Check whether the EGR cooler is being clogged or not.
noteWhen checking the clogged EGR cooler, make a visual check or use an air blower.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Replace the EGR cooler.
 
STEP 7. Check on clogged EGR pipe (A, B)
Check whether the EGR pipe (A, B) is being clogged or not.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the EGR pipe (A, B).
 
STEP 8. Check on clogged EGR cooler by-pass valve
Check whether the EGR cooler by-pass valve is being clogged or not.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the EGR cooler by-pass valve.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0106 MANIFOLD ABSOLUTE PRESSURE SENSOR RANGE/PERFORMANCE PROBLEM<4N15>
Code No. P0106: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0106: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The manifold absolute pressure sensor converts the manifold absolute pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
  • The following 3 conditions are formed:
    1. The engine cooling water temperature is from 80 to 115°C.
    2. The intake air temperature is from -5 to 80°C.
    3. The atmospheric pressure is from 76 to 120 kPa.
Judgement Criterion
  • When an idle state and an engine rotation speed of 2,000 r/min continue for 3 seconds, manifold absolute pressure are read and the difference between them goes under 800 Pa for 5 seconds.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Vacuum hose clogged between manifold absolute pressure sensor and inlet manifold
  • Failed manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Manifold absolute pressure sensor circuit harness damage or loose connector contact
  • EGR cooler clogged
  • EGR pipe (A, B) clogged
  • EGR cooler by-pass valve clogged
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check for vacuum hose for clogs between manifold absolute pressure sensor and inlet manifold
  • Check whether the vacuum hose is clogged between the manifold absolute pressure sensor and the inlet manifold, which is caused by dirt and the hose folded. Also check the inside inlet manifold and the nipple that can be possibly contaminated with dirt.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP5.
    • Check power supply line for damage.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAPE line and body earth.
OK: 0.5 V or less
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAPE.
    • Check earthing line for damage.
 
STEP 5. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON"
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP line and body earth.
OK: The voltage should be 0.7 to 1.2 V. When the accelerator pedal is quickly depressed from the idling state, the voltage temporarily rises.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the manifold absolute pressure sensor.
 
STEP 6. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal MAP and body earth.
OK: The voltage should be 0.7 to 1.2 V. When the accelerator pedal is quickly depressed from the idling state, the voltage temporarily rises.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP.
    • Check output line for damage.
 
STEP 7. Check on clogged EGR cooler
Check whether the EGR cooler is being clogged or not.
noteWhen checking the clogged EGR cooler, make a visual check or use an air blower.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the EGR cooler.
 
STEP 8. Check on clogged EGR pipe (A, B)
Check whether the EGR pipe (A, B) is being clogged or not.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the EGR pipe (A, B).
 
STEP 9. Check on clogged EGR cooler by-pass valve
Check whether the EGR cooler by-pass valve is being clogged or not.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Replace the EGR cooler by-pass valve.
 
STEP 10. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0107 MANIFOLD ABSOLUTE PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0107: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0106: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The manifold absolute pressure sensor converts the manifold absolute pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The manifold absolute pressure sensor output voltage 0.28 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed manifold absolute pressure sensor.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in manifold absolute pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU.

STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?

  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.

Check power supply line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. Perform resistance measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU MAPE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAPE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Perform voltage measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU MAP line and body earth.
OK: 0.7 to 1.2 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Go to Step 8.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the manifold absolute pressure sensor.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. Check harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP
Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.

  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal MAP and body earth.
OK: 0.7 to 1.2 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAP.
    • Check output line for open circuit and damage.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0108 MANIFOLD ABSOLUTE PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0108: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0106: Manifold Absolute Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The manifold absolute pressure sensor converts the manifold absolute pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.

Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up
Judgement Criterion

FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Open circuit in manifold absolute pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at manifold absolute pressure sensor connector
  • Disconnect and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU MAPE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between manifold absolute pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal MAPE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the manifold absolute pressure sensor.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0112 EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0112: EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the EGR gas temperature sensor output terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal ETS.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal ETSE from the EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor converts the EGR gas temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the EGR gas temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the EGR gas temperature, and becomes lower as the EGR gas temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor output voltage is 0.11 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The intake air temperature is controlled to be 50°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Short circuit in EGR gas temperature sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself
  • EGR gas temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Check ). <4N14>
  • Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N15>, EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Check ). <4N15>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR gas temperature sensor.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at EGR gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON"
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU ETS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETS
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at EGR gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU ETSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0113 EGR GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0113: EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0112: EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor converts the EGR gas temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the EGR gas temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the EGR gas temperature, and becomes lower as the EGR gas temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR gas temperature sensor output voltage is 4.96 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The intake air temperature is controlled to be 50°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Open circuit or harness damage in EGR gas temperature sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself
  • EGR gas temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Check ). <4N14>
  • Check EGR gas temperature sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N15>, EGR Gas Temperature Sensor Check ). <4N15>
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR gas temperature sensor.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at EGR gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU ETS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETS
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at EGR gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU ETSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between EGR gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ETS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0117 ENGINE COOLANT TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0117: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> output terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal WTS.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal WTSE from the engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> converts the engine coolant temperature into a voltage signal, and inputs the voltage to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls the fuel infection amount and the fast idle speed when the engine is cold state.
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the engine coolant temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the engine coolant temperature, and becomes lower as the engine coolant temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> output voltage is 0.15 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The engine coolant temperature is controlled to be 80°C (Start-up of -25°C).
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15>
  • Short circuit in engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
OK:
  • Engine cold state: At ambient temperature (atmospheric temperature) or equivalent.
  • Engine hot state: At 80 to 120°C
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15>
  • Engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15> check.
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at sensor side.
  • Resistance between terminals.
OK:
  • Engine coolant temperature at -20°C: 14 to 17 kΩ
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 0°C: 5.1 to 6.5 kΩ)
  • Engine coolant temperature at 20°C: 2.1 to 2.7 kΩ
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 40°C: 0.9 to 1.3 kΩ)
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 60°C: 0.48 to 0.68 kΩ)
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 80°C: 0.26 to 0.36 kΩ)
note( ): Reference value.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15>.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15>
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU WTS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTS <4N14> or between engine coolant temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTS <4N15>
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
OK:
  • Engine cold state: At ambient temperature (atmospheric temperature) or equivalent.
  • Engine hot state: At 80 to 120°C
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15>
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU WTSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTSE <4N14> or between engine coolant temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTSE <4N15>
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTS <4N14> or between engine coolant temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WTS <4N15>
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0118 ENGINE COOLANT TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0118: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0117: Engine Coolant Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> converts the engine coolant temperature into a voltage signal, and inputs the voltage to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls the fuel infection amount and the fast idle speed when the engine is cold state.
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the engine coolant temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the engine coolant temperature, and becomes lower as the engine coolant temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> output voltage is 4.95 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The engine coolant temperature is controlled to be 80°C (Start-up of -25°C).
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15>
  • Open circuit or harness damage in engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15> circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
OK:
  • Engine cold state: At ambient temperature (atmospheric temperature) or equivalent.
  • Engine hot state: At 80 to 120°C
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15>
  • Engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 connector <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor connector <4N15> check.
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at sensor side.
  • Resistance between terminals.
OK:
  • Engine coolant temperature at -20°C: 14 to 17 kΩ
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 0°C: 5.1 to 6.5 kΩ)
  • Engine coolant temperature at 20°C: 2.1 to 2.7 kΩ
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 40°C: 0.9 to 1.3 kΩ)
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 60°C: 0.48 to 0.68 kΩ)
  • (Engine coolant temperature at 80°C: 0.26 to 0.36 kΩ)
note( ): Reference value.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine coolant temperature sensor No. 1 <4N14> or engine coolant temperature sensor <4N15>.

  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU WTS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.

Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.

  • Engine hot state: At 80 to 120°C

  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU WTSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0122 THROTTLE POSITION SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0122: Throttle Position Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal TPS5.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal TPSE from the electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal.
  • The sensor signal is inputted to the engine-ECU connector terminal TPSM from the electronic-controlled throttle valve output terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The throttle position sensor converts the throttle valve position into voltage and inputs it into the engine-ECU.
  • The engine-ECU control the throttle valve position.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up
Judgement Criterion
  • The throttle position sensor output voltage is 0.15 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed throttle position sensor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in throttle position sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at electronic-controlled throttle valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON " position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU TPS5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPS5
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. Perform resistance measurement at electronic-controlled throttle valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU TPSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Perform voltage measurement at electronic-controlled throttle valve connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991658) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON " position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU TPSM line and body earth.
OK: 3.7 V or higher
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Go to Step 8.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPSM
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPS5
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the throttle body assembly.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPSM
Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0123 THROTTLE POSITION SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0123: Throttle Position Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0122: Throttle Position Sensor Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The throttle position sensor converts the throttle valve position into voltage and inputs it into the engine-ECU.
  • The engine-ECU control the throttle valve position.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up
Judgement Criterion
  • The throttle position sensor output voltage is 4.85 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed throttle position sensor
  • Open circuit or harness damage in throttle position sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at electronic-controlled throttle valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU TPSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between electronic-controlled throttle valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal TPSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the throttle body assembly
After replacing the throttle body assembly, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the throttle body assembly.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0123 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0182 FUEL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0182: Fuel Temperature Sensor Circuit Low input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Fuel temperature sensor is built into the supply pump assembly.
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the fuel temperature sensor output terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal FTS.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal FTSE from the fuel temperature sensor connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The fuel temperature sensor converts the fuel temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.
  • The fuel temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the fuel temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the fuel temperature, and becomes lower as the fuel temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The fuel temperature sensor output voltage is 0.10 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The fuel temperature is controlled to be 45°C (Start-up of -25°C).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed supply pump assembly (integrated with fuel temperature sensor)
  • Short circuit in fuel temperature sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
OK: At ambient temperature (fuel temperature) or equivalent.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check fuel temperature sensor itself
  • Fuel temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check fuel temperature sensor itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the supply pump assembly (integrated with fuel temperature sensor).
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at fuel temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU FTS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between fuel temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FTS
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
OK: At ambient temperature (fuel temperature) or equivalent.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at fuel temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU FTSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between fuel temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FTSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between fuel temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FTS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0183 FUEL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0183: Fuel Temperature Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0182: Fuel Temperature Sensor Circuit Low input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The fuel temperature sensor converts the fuel temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection amount, etc.
  • The fuel temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the fuel temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the fuel temperature, and becomes lower as the fuel temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The fuel temperature sensor output voltage is 4.95 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The fuel temperature is controlled to be 45°C (Start-up of -25°C).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed supply pump assembly (integrated with fuel temperature sensor)
  • Open circuit or harness damage in fuel temperature sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
OK: At ambient temperature (fuel temperature) or equivalent.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check fuel temperature sensor itself
  • Fuel temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check fuel temperature sensor itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the supply pump assembly (integrated with fuel temperature sensor).
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at fuel temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU FTS line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between fuel temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FTS
Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
OK: At ambient temperature (fuel temperature) or equivalent.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at fuel temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU FTSE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between fuel temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FTSE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0191 RAIL PRESSURE SENSOR RANGE/PERFORMANCE PROBLEM
Code No. P0191: Rail Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Rail pressure sensor is built into the common rail assembly.
  • 5 V power is supplied from the engine-ECU connector terminal FPS5 to the rail pressure sensor connector terminal.
  • The rail pressure sensor connector terminal is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal FPSE.
  • Sensor signals are input from the rail pressure sensor connector terminal to the engine-ECU connector terminal FPS.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU monitors the signals input from the rail pressure sensor.
  • Based on these signals, the engine-ECU checks the rail pressure sensor for errors.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Engine is running.
Judgement Criterion
  • A difference between the objective and actual rail pressures exceeds 15 MPa, and the rail pressure sensor has an output voltage variation of 0.01 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure is controlled in the range between 50 and 100 MPa.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The throttle valve is closed (Fixed opening degree).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed common rail assembly (integrated with rail pressure sensor)
  • Harness damage in rail pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed suction control valve
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check suction control valve itself
  • Suction control valve connector check.
  • Check suction control valve itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the suction control valve.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between rail pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FPSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between rail pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FPS5
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between rail pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FPS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Perform voltage measurement at rail pressure sensor connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991658) to connect connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Engine: Idling (after warming up)
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU FPS line and body earth.
OK: 1.15 to 1.75 V
Is the check result normal?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Replace the common rail assembly (integrated with rail pressure sensor) and fuel injection tubes.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0192 RAIL PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0192: Rail Pressure Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0191: Rail Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure sensor converts the rail pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection quantity.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The rail pressure sensor output voltage is 0.70 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure is controlled in the range between 50 and 100 MPa.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The throttle valve is closed (Fixed opening degree).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed common rail assembly (integrated with rail pressure sensor)
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in rail pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at fuel pressure sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU FPS line and body earth.
OK: No continuity
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between rail pressure sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FPS
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Voltage measurement at rail pressure sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at sensor side.
  • With the special tool test harness (MB991658) bridge only the mating terminals of engine-ECU FPS5 line and engine-ECU FPSE line of the disconnected connector.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU FPS line and body earth.
OK: 0.85 V or more
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the common rail assembly (integrated with rail pressure sensor).
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0193 RAIL PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0193: Rail Pressure Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0191: Rail Pressure Sensor Range/Performance Problem .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure sensor converts the rail pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU corrects the fuel injection quantity.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The rail pressure sensor output voltage is 4.85 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure is controlled in the range between 50 and 100 MPa.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The throttle valve is closed (Fixed opening degree).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.

OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V

Check power supply line for open/short circuit.

Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.

  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU FPS line and body earth.
OK: 0.85 V or more
Is the check result normal?
