STEP 2. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR+ and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR- and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5 and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check EGR valve itself
  • EGR valve connector check.
  • Check EGR valve itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, Exhaust Gas Recirculation Valve (DC motor) Check <4N14> or <4N15>].
Is the check result normal?
YES <4N14> : Go to Step 8.
YES <4N15> : Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR valve.
 
STEP 8. Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself <4N14>
Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, EGR Cooler Bypass Actuator Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
 
STEP 9. Check EGR passage for deposits
Check the EGR valve, the EGR valve pipe and the inside of the EGR cooler for deposits. (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N14> or <4N15>).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Cleaning or replace the EGR valve, EGR valve pipe and EGR cooler.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 11. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 12. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor and common tubes.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0401 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0402 EGR FLOW EXCESSIVE
Code No. P0402: EGR Flow Excessive
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Refer to Code No. P0102: Air Flow Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14> .
  • Refer to Code No. P0403: EGR Valve DC Motor Malfunction .
  • Refer to Code No. P0489: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
The engine-ECU monitors the EGR flow rate.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • The amount of fuel consumption, the engine speed, the target lambda, the gear position, the vehicle speed, the intake air temperature and the atmospheric pressure are within the threshold values.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR flow rate is higher than the specified value.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR passage (air suction)
  • Failed connector or harness damage of EGR valve system
  • Failed EGR valve operation
  • Failed EGR cooler bypass actuator operation <4N14>
  • Failed connector or harness damage of air flow sensor system
  • Failed air flow sensor (abnormal output characteristics)
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0403 or No. P2413 set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis codes (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR+ and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR- and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5 and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check EGR valve itself
  • EGR valve connector check.
  • Check EGR valve itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, Exhaust Gas Recirculation Valve (DC motor) Check <4N14> or <4N15>].
Is the check result normal?
YES <4N14> : Go to Step 8.
YES <4N15> : Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR valve.
 
STEP 8. Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself <4N14>
Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, EGR Cooler Bypass Actuator Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
 
STEP 9. Check EGR passage for deposits
Check the EGR valve, the EGR valve pipe and the inside of the EGR cooler for deposits. (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N14> or <4N15>).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Cleaning or replace the EGR valve, EGR valve pipe and EGR cooler.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFSE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 11. Check harness between air flow sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AFS
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 12. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the air flow sensor
After replacing the air flow sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the air flow sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0402 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0403 EGR VALVE DC MOTOR MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0403: EGR Valve DC Motor Malfunction
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The electric current from the engine-ECU connector terminal EGR+ and EGR- to the exhaust gas recirculation valve (DC motor) connector terminal is controlled.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU performs duty control over the EGR valve (DC motor).
  • The engine-ECU performs feedback control over the EGR valve based on the signals from the EGR valve position sensor.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is in "ON" position
Judgement Criterion
  • An over current cut-off signal from the EGR valve drive control integrated circuit (IC) is detected.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR valve
  • Failed EGR cooler bypass actuator <4N14>
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in EGR valve circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check EGR valve itself
  • EGR valve connector check.
  • Check EGR valve itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, Exhaust Gas Recirculation Valve (DC motor) Check <4N14> or <4N15>].
Is the check result normal?
YES <4N14> : Go to Step 2.
YES <4N15> : Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR valve.
 
STEP 2. Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself <4N14>
Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System, EGR Cooler Bypass Actuator Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR+ and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal EGR- and exhaust gas recirculation valve connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0403 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0420 CATALYST MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0420: Catalyst Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU injects the fuel with the slower timing than usual (post injection), so that the oxygen and HC of exhaust gas burn in the catalyst, and the exhaust gas temperature raises up to the level which enables the DPF regeneration.
  • The engine-ECU monitors the signals from the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) to detect the catalyst inactivation.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • On DPF regeneration
Judgement Criteria
  • The conditions below continues for 30 seconds.
  • The fuel injection amount exceeds the specified value.
  • The engine speed exceeds the specified value.
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor is 350°C or higher.
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) is 450°C or below.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
  • Failed No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
  • Catalytic converter inactive
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 2.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to Inspection Chart for Diagnosis Code ).
 
STEP 2. Diagnosis code recheck after forcible DPF regeneration execution
After forcible DPF regeneration execution, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Initialise the DPF-related parts, and then erase the diagnosis code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
  • Item No. 42: DPF system malfunction service
(2) Carry out the forcible DPF regeneration (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>).
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Engine: Idle operation after warm-up
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0420 or No. P1497 set?
Replace the catalytic converter. When the catalytic converter is replaced, initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ). On completion, carry out the forcible DPF regeneration (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System - Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0427 NO. 2 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR (CATALYST TEMPERATURE) CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0427: No. 2 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor (Catalyst Temperature) Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) output terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal DTS2.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal DT2E from the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) converts the catalyst temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Engine-ECU uses this voltage output for DPF regeneration control.
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the catalyst temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the catalyst temperature, and becomes lower as the catalyst temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) output voltage is 0.255 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature is controlled to be 0°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
  • Short circuit in No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) itself
  • No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector check.
  • Check No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, No. 2 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor (catalyst temperature) Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature). After replacing the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature), carry out the forcible DPF regeneration. [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>].
 
STEP 3. Check harness between No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS2
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0428 NO. 2 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR (CATALYST TEMPERATURE) CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0428: No. 2 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor (Catalyst Temperature) Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0427: No. 2 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor (Catalyst Temperature) Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) converts the catalyst temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Engine-ECU uses this voltage for DPF regeneration control.
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the catalyst temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the catalyst temperature, and becomes lower as the catalyst temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
  • Vehicle speed is 20 km/h or higher.
Judgement Criterion
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) output voltage is 4.95 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The No. 2 exhaust gas temperature is controlled to be 0°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
  • Open circuit or harness damage in No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) itself
  • No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector check.
  • Check No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, No. 2 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor (catalyst temperature) Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature). After replacing the No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature), carry out the forcible DPF regeneration. [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>].
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU DTS2 line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS2
Check output line for open circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU DT2E line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DT2E
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature) connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS2
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0489 EGR VALVE POSITION SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0489: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) valve position sensor is built into the EGR valve.
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the EGR valve power terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5 and earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE from the EGR valve connector terminal.
  • The sensor signal is inputted to the engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP from the EGR valve output terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The EGR valve detects the position of the EGR valve and sends the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Based on the signal, the engine-ECU performs the feedback control of the EGR valve.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR valve position sensor output voltage is 0.20 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR valve (with built-in EGR valve position sensor).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in EGR valve position sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Use special tool test harness(MB991658) to connect connector and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU EGR5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5
Check power supply line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. Perform resistance measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU EGRE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Perform voltage measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991658) to connect connector and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Engine: Idling (after warming up)
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU EGRP line and body earth.
OK: 2.0 V or higher
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Go to Step 8.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the EGR valve.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP
Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0489 EGR VALVE POSITION SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N15>
Code No. P0489: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0489: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The EGR valve detects the position of the EGR valve and sends the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Based on the signal, the engine-ECU performs the feedback control of the EGR valve.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR valve position sensor output voltage is 0.20 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR valve (with built-in EGR valve position sensor).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in EGR valve position sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Use special tool test harness(MB991658) to connect connector and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU EGR5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal EGR5 and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5.
    • Check power supply line for open circuit and damage.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGR5
Check power supply line for short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU EGRE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Perform voltage measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Use special tool test harness (MB991658) to connect connector and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Engine: Idling (after warming up)
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU EGRP line and body earth.
OK: 2.0 V or higher
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Go to Step 9.
 
STEP 9. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the EGR valve.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 10. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idling (after warming up)
  • Voltage between terminal EGRP and body earth.
OK: 2.0 V or higher
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRP.
    • Check output line for open circuit and damage.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0490 EGR VALVE POSITION SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0490: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0489: EGR Valve Position Sensor Circuit Low Input <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The EGR valve detects the position of the EGR valve and sends the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Based on the signal, the engine-ECU performs the feedback control of the EGR valve.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The EGR valve position sensor output voltage is 4.80 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
The EGR control is stopped (fully closed).
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed EGR valve (with built-in EGR valve position sensor).
  • Open circuit or harness damage in EGR valve position sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at EGR valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU EGRE line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between EGR valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal EGRE
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the EGR valve.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0500 VEHICLE SPEED SIGNAL SYSTEM
Code No. P0500: Vehicle Speed Signal Low Input
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The engine-ECU receives vehicle speed signal from ASTC-ECU via the CAN communication.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • CAN communication is normal
  • Battery positive voltage is more than 10 V and is less than 16.5 V.
Judgement Criterion
  • The vehicle speed information received from the CAN is abnormal, or the CAN signal cannot be received.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed wheel speed sensor of ASTC.
  • Failed ASTC-ECU
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check for diagnosis code of other system
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check if the diagnosis code is set in the ASTC-ECU.
Is any diagnosis code set in the ASTC-ECU?
Perform troubleshooting of the active stability control (ASTC) system (Refer to GROUP 35C - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 4: Vehicle speed sensor
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Replace the ASTC-ECU.
 
STEP 3. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and driving the vehicle.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0500 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0513 IMMOBILIZER MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0513: Immobilizer Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU transmits to and receives from KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>, ETACS-ECU <Vehicles without KOS> a control signal to authenticate the ignition key.
    note
    • This code may be displayed due to radio interference if there are multiple registered ignition keys nearby during engine start.
    • This code may be displayed when the transponder ID code is registered.
    • This code is also displayed when the ignition key code is not recognised.
    • When this code is displayed, it is also sent to KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS> or ETACS-ECU <Vehicles without KOS>.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is in "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • The check result of the KOS&OSS-ECU is not suitable for that of the engine-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>.
  • The check result of the ETACS-ECU is not suitable for that of the engine-ECU <Vehicles without KOS>.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
The AS&G control is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>
  • Failed ETACS-ECU <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check for diagnosis code of other system
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check if the diagnosis code is set in the KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS> or ETACS-ECU <Vehicles without KOS>.
Is any diagnosis code set in the KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS> or ETACS-ECU <Vehicles without KOS>?
Perform the troubleshooting of KOS-system (Refer to GROUP 42B - Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart <Vehicles with KOS>) or the troubleshooting of KOS-system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Immobilizer System, Troubleshooting, Diagnosis Code Chart <Vehicles without KOS>).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0513 set?
Replace the KOS&OSS-ECU. After the replacement, put the each identification code into KOS&OSS-ECU (Refer to GROUP 42B - On-vehicle Service, ID Codes Registration Procedures <Vehicles with KOS>). Or replace the ETACS-ECU. After the replacement, put the each identification code into ETACS-ECU (Refer to GROUP 54A - Immobilizer System, On-vehicle Service, ID Codes Registration Procedures <Vehicles without KOS>). Then go to Step 3.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 3. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0513 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0515 BATTERY TEMPERATURE SENSOR SYSTEM<4N14>
Code No. P0515: Battery Temperature Sensor System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Power is supplied by the battery to the battery current sensor.
  • The battery current sensor (integrated with battery temperature sensor) sends a signal to the engine-ECU connector terminal LNBS via the Local Interconnect Network (LIN).
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The battery temperature sensor is incorporated into the battery current sensor and it informs the engine-ECU of battery temperature via the Local Interconnect Network (LIN).
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls charging and discharging.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • After 2 seconds since the ignition switch is turned ON or since the completion of engine start.
  • Battery positive voltage is more than 10 V and is less than 16.5 V.
Judgement Criterion
  • For 2 seconds, the battery temperature information from battery temperature sensor is abnormal.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • Prohibits alternator output suppression control against current consumers (operates as a normal alternator).
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery current sensor (integrated with battery temperature sensor).
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0622 or No. P1538 set?
Troubleshoot the diagnosis codes (Refer to <P0622> or <P1538>).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0515 set?
Go to Step 3.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 3. Diagnosis code recheck after replace the battery current sensor
After replacing the battery current sensor, check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Replacing the battery current sensor.
(2) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(4) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(5) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0515 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0522 OIL PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0522: Oil Pressure Sensor Low <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The engine oil temperature sensor is built into the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor.
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector power supply terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal OPS5 and earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal OPSG from the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector earth terminal.
  • The sensor signal is inputted to the engine-ECU connector terminal OPS from the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector output terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine oil pressure sensor converts the oil pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • The engine-ECU uses this signal for relief control of engine oil pressure.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The engine oil pressure sensor output voltage is 0.15 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
None
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine oil pressure and temperature sensor (integrated with engine oil pressure sensor)
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine oil pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPS5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPS
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • With the special tool test harness (MB991658) bridge only the mating terminals of engine-ECU OPS5 line and engine-ECU OPSG line of the disconnected connector.
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPS line and body earth.
OK: The voltage increases in accordance with the increase of the engine speed.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor (integrated with engine oil pressure sensor).
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPS5
Check power supply line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0522 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0523 OIL PRESSURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT<4N14>
Code No. P0523: Oil Pressure Sensor High <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0522: Oil Pressure Sensor Low <4N14> .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine oil pressure sensor converts the oil pressure into a voltage signal and inputs the signal to the engine-ECU.
  • The engine-ECU uses this signal for relief control of engine oil pressure.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The engine oil pressure sensor output voltage is 4.75 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
None
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine oil pressure and temperature sensor (integrated with engine oil pressure sensor).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine oil pressure sensor circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPSG
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPS5 line and body earth.
OK: 4.9 to 5.1 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPS
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • With the special tool test harness (MB991658) bridge only the mating terminals of engine-ECU OPS5 line and engine-ECU OPSG line of the disconnected connector.
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPS line and body earth.
OK: The voltage increases in accordance with the increase of the engine speed.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor (integrated with engine oil pressure sensor).
 
STEP 5. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPS5
Check power supply line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and start the engine.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0523 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0537 A/C EVAPORATOR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0537: A/C Evaporator Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the fin thermo sensor connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal AC/T.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal ACTE from the fin thermo sensor connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The fin thermo sensor converts the evaporator surface temperature into a voltage signal, and sends the voltage to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls the A/C compressor relay.
  • The fin thermo sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as air temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the air temperature, and becomes lower as the air temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • Fin thermo sensor output voltage is 4.863 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
Control as if the evaporator surface temperature is -6.4°C.
 
 
CAUSES
  • Failed fin thermo sensor
  • Short circuit in fin thermo sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 174: Fin thermo sensor
OK:
  • Evaporator surface temperature is the same as M.U.T.-III displayed temperature.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check fin thermo sensor itself
  • Fin thermo sensor connector check.
  • Check fin thermo sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 55A - Heater Unit and Cooling Unit, Inspection, Fin Thermo Sensor Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fin thermo sensor.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at fin thermo sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal AC/T line and earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between fin thermo sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/T
Check output line for short to earth.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 174: Fin thermo sensor
OK:
  • Evaporator surface temperature is the same as M.U.T.-III displayed temperature.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0538 A/C EVAPORATOR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0538: A/C Evaporator Temperature Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0537: A/C Evaporator Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The fin thermo sensor converts the evaporator surface temperature into a voltage signal, and sends the voltage to the engine-ECU.
  • In response to the signal, the engine-ECU controls the A/C compressor relay.
  • The fin thermo sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as air temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the air temperature, and becomes lower as the air temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • Fin thermo sensor output voltage is 0.122 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
Control as if the evaporator surface temperature is -6.4°C.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed fin thermo sensor
  • Open circuit or harness damage in fin thermo sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 174: Fin thermo sensor
OK:
  • Evaporator surface temperature is the same as M.U.T.-III displayed temperature.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check fin thermo sensor itself
  • Fin thermo sensor connector check.
  • Check fin thermo sensor itself (Refer to GROUP 55A - Heater Unit and Cooling Unit, Inspection, Fin Thermo Sensor Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fin thermo sensor.
 
STEP 3. Perform resistance measurement at fin thermo sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal ACTE line and earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between fin thermo sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ACTE
Check earthing line for open circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 174: Fin thermo sensor
OK:
  • Evaporator surface temperature is the same as M.U.T.-III displayed temperature.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform voltage measurement at fin thermo sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal AC/T line and earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between fin thermo sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/T
Check output line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between fin thermo sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/T
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0545 NO. 1 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT LOW INPUT
Code No. P0545: No. 1 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • A power voltage of 5 V is applied to the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor output terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal DTS1.
  • The power voltage is earthed to the engine-ECU connector terminal DT1E from the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor converts the exhaust gas temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Engine-ECU uses this voltage output for DPF regeneration control.
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the exhaust gas temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the exhaust gas temperature, and becomes lower as the exhaust gas temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
Judgement Criterion
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor output voltage is 0.12 V or less.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature is controlled to be 0°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
  • Short circuit in No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor circuit or connector damage
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor itself
  • No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, No. 1 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor. After replacing the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor, carry out the forcible DPF regeneration [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>].
 
STEP 3. Check harness between No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS1
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0546 NO. 1 EXHAUST GAS TEMPERATURE SENSOR CIRCUIT HIGH INPUT
Code No. P0546: No. 1 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit High Input
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Refer to Code No. P0545: No. 1 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Circuit Low Input .
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor converts the exhaust gas temperature into a voltage and inputs the voltage signal to the engine-ECU.
  • Engine-ECU uses this voltage for DPF regeneration control.
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor is a kind of resistor, which has characteristics to reduce its resistance as the exhaust gas temperature rises. Therefore, the sensor output voltage varies with the exhaust gas temperature, and becomes lower as the exhaust gas temperature rises.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Battery positive voltage is 8 to 16 V.
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
  • Vehicle speed is 20 km/h or higher.
Judgement Criterion
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor output voltage is 4.95 V or more.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The No. 1 exhaust gas temperature is controlled to be 0°C.
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
  • Open circuit or harness damage in No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor itself
  • No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector check.
  • Check No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, No. 1 Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor. After replacing the No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor, carry out the forcible DPF regeneration [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Diesel Particulate Filter (DPF) System, Forcible DPF Regeneration <4N14> or <4N15>].
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU DTS1 line and body earth.
OK: 4.5 to 4.9 V
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS1
Check output line for open circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 6. Perform resistance measurement at No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal engine-ECU DT1E line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DT1E
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal DTS1
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0551 POWER STEERING FLUID PRESSURE SWITCH SYSTEM
Code No. P0551: Power Steering Fluid Pressure Switch System
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The battery voltage is applied to the power steering fluid pressure switch connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal P/S.
 
 
FUNCTION
It is detected whether a load is applied on the power steering fluid pump by steering or not, and the signal is inputted to the engine-ECU. When the power steering fluid pressure switch on signal (a large load on the power steering fluid pump) is inputted, the engine-ECU provides the idle-up control.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Within 5 seconds after the ignition switch is in the "LOCK" (OFF) position.
Judgement Criterion
  • For 2 seconds, the power steering fluid pressure switch is in the on position and the engine continuously stops.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed power steering fluid pressure switch
  • Open circuit or harness damage in power steering fluid pressure switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 75: Power steering fluid pressure switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform resistance measurement at power steering fluid pressure switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Resistance between terminal P/S line and body earth.
OK: No continuity
Is the check result normal?
Replace the power steering fluid pressure switch.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at power steering fluid pressure switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal P/S line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between power steering fluid pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal P/S
Check output line for open/short circuit or damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 75: Power steering fluid pressure switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P05EA OIL BYPASS VALVE CONTROL CIRCUIT ABNORMAL<4N14>
Code No. P05EA: Engine Oil Bypass Valve Control Circuit Abnormal <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Power is supplied to the oil relief control valve connector terminal from the engine control relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal OCV2 makes the power transistor in the unit be in "ON" position, and that makes currents go on the oil relief control valve connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
The oil relief control valve changes the valve opening pressure of the oil relief valve according to the signals from the engine-ECU, and decreases the oil pressure applied to the engine.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • Ignition switch is "ON" position
  • During the oil relief control valve operation*.
note*: The operating conditions of the il relief control valve are as follows:
  • Engine speed is 1,000 r/min or more and 3,000 r/min or less.
  • Engine load is 100 N·m or more and 200 N·m or less.
  • The small injection quantity learning is not in progress.
Judgement Criterion
  • A malfunction is detected in the oil relief control valve circuit.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed oil cooler bracket (integrated with oil relief control valve).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in oil relief control valve circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform resistance measurement at oil relief control valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at oil relief control valve side.
  • Resistance between terminals.
OK: 6.7 to 7.7 Ω (at 20°C)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the oil cooler bracket (integrated with oil relief control valve).
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at oil relief control valve connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine control relay connector terminal and oil relief control valve connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between oil relief control valve connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OCV2
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position and during the oil relief control valve operation.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P05EA set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0602 VARIANT CODING SYSTEM
Code No. P0602: Variant Coding System
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU performs proper engine control based on vehicle information entered.
  • A vehicle information is entered at a plant before shipment. This diagnosis code occurs when no vehicle information is entered during engine-ECU replacement.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • Vehicle information is not entered into the engine-ECU.
or
  • The tester write area of EEPROM is abnormal.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
None.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0602 set?
Replace the engine-ECU with one into which vehicle information is correctly entered.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0604 RANDOM ACCESS MEMORY (RAM) MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0604: Random Access Memory (RAM) Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU writes information to RAM or reads information from RAM.
  • The engine-ECU performs an initial check to detect errors in RAM.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is in "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • A destroyed RAM is detected by engine-ECU initial check.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The engine is stopped (The fuel injection and pump pressure feed are stopped).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The throttle valve is opened (Electrical discontinuity).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0604 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0605 READ ONLY MEMORY (FLASH ROM) MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0605: Read Only Memory (FLASH ROM) Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
  • The engine-ECU reads information from flash ROM.
  • The engine-ECU detects checksum errors.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is in "ON" position.
Judgement Criterion
  • In each inspection target area of a flash ROM, a checksum mismatch is detected three times consecutively.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure is controlled in the range between 50 and 100 MPa.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The throttle valve is closed (Fixed opening degree).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0605 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0606 ENGINE-ECU (MAIN CPU) MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0606: Engine-ECU (main CPU) Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The engine-ECU check whether the microcomputer, which performs the drive control of the throttle valve, is normal.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Condition
  • Ignition switch is in "ON" position
Judgement Criterion
  • The monitoring microcomputer detects a main microcomputer error.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
  • The rail pressure is controlled in the range between 50 and 100 MPa.
  • The fuel injection amount is restricted (Output restriction).
  • The open angle of the accelerator pedal is restricted.
  • The throttle valve is closed (Fixed opening degree).
  • The EGR control is stopped (Fully closed).
  • The DPF regeneration is prohibited.
  • The turbocharger control is prohibited.
  • The AS&G control is prohibited.
  • The small injection quantity learning is prohibited.
  • The speed limiter control is prohibited.
  • The cruise control is prohibit.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
Failed engine-ECU

 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Diagnosis code recheck after erasing diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Check again if the diagnosis code is set.
(1) Use M.U.T.-III to erase the diagnosis code.
(2) Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
(3) Turn the ignition switch to "ON" position.
(4) Use M.U.T.-III to recheck the diagnosis code.
Is diagnosis code No. P0606 set?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > DIAGNOSIS CODE PROCEDURES > CODE NO. P0607 ENGINE-ECU (SUB CPU) MALFUNCTION
Code No. P0607: Engine-ECU (sub CPU) Malfunction
 
 
 
 
FUNCTION
The main microcomputer detects errors in the sub microcomputer used for monitoring.
 
 
TROUBLE JUDGEMENT
Check Conditions
  • 2 seconds later after the ignition switch has been in "ON" position or the engine has started up.
  • Battery positive voltage is 10 V or more
Judgement Criterion
  • The main microcomputer detects a monitoring microcomputer error.
 
 
FAIL-SAFE AND BACKUP FUNCTION
