13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > COMMUNICATION WITH ENGINE-ECU IS NOT POSSIBLE
Inspection Procedure 1: Communication with Engine-ECU is Not Possible
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Battery voltage is applied to the diagnosis connector terminal.
  • The diagnosis connector terminal is earthed to the vehicle body.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
When the communication between M.U.T.-III and the engine-ECU is impossible, the CAN bus line, power supply circuit of the diagnosis connector, and/or earthing circuit could possibly be defective. The communication cannot be achieved either if the wrong vehicle type is selected on M.U.T.-III.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Defective diagnosis connector
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in diagnosis connector circuit or loose connector contact
  • Defective CAN communication
  • Defective M.U.T.-III
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check the Vehicle Communication Interface (V.C.I.) operations
  • Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
  • When the power of Vehicle Communication Interface (V.C.I.) is turned to ON, the indicator lamp of the Vehicle Communication Interface (V.C.I.) illuminates in green.
OK: The indicator lamp of the Vehicle Communication Interface (V.C.I.) illuminates in green.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at diagnosis connector
Voltage between terminal power supply lines and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between the battery and diagnosis connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Perform resistance measurement at diagnosis connector
Resistance between terminal earthing lines and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between the diagnosis connector terminal and body earth
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III CAN bus diagnosis
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform CAN bus line diagnosis.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Correct CAN bus line (Refer to GROUP 54C - Troubleshooting <CAN>, Can Bus Diagnostics Table ). Then go to Step 6.
 
STEP 8. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Check engine-ECU power supply system (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points - How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 9. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 1.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE ENGINE WARNING LAMP DOES NOT ILLUMINATE RIGHT AFTER THE IGNITION SWITCH IS TURNED TO THE "ON" POSITION
Inspection Procedure 2: The Engine Warning Lamp Does Not Illuminate Right After the Ignition Switch is Turned to the "ON" Position
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The combination meter illuminates the engine warning lamp just after the ignition switch is in the "ON" position.
  • If the engine warning lamp is not illuminated just after the ignition switch is in the "ON" position, the failure could possibly be caused by the defective engine warning lamp, open/short circuit of the combination meter and so on.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine warning lamp
  • Open/short circuit in the combination meter
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Check combination meter system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Trouble Symptom Chart ).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE ENGINE WARNING LAMP REMAINS ILLUMINATING AND NEVER GOES OUT
Inspection Procedure 3: The Engine Warning Lamp Remains Illuminating and Never Goes Out
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The engine-ECU detects failures, or the failures could possibly be caused by the short circuit of the combination meter and so on.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
Failed combination meter
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Check combination meter system (Refer to GROUP 54A - Combination Meter, Trouble Symptom Chart ).
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE STARTER IS IMPOSSIBLE TO OPERATE<4N15-M/T>
Inspection Procedure 4: Starter Impossible (Starter not Operative) <4N15-M/T>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The power source is supplied from the battery to the starter connector terminal.
  • The battery voltage is applied to the starter relay connector terminal.
  • When the ignition switch "ST" signal is input to the engine-ECU connector terminal ST, the engine-ECU connector terminal STRL turns ON the power transistor inside the unit, and makes the current flow into the starter relay connector terminal to turn ON the relay.
  • When the starter relay is turned ON, the current flows into the starter connector terminal from the starter relay connector terminal to drive the starter motor.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The failure could possibly be caused by the malfunction of the starter or starter system circuits.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Failed ignition switch <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Failed KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>
  • Failed starter relay
  • Failed starter motor
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in starter system circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed clutch interlock switch
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 40: Starter switch
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU ST line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
NO <Vehicles without KOS> : Go to Step 4.
NO <Vehicles with KOS> : Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 4. Check ignition switch itself <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Ignition switch connector check.
  • Check ignition switch itself (Refer to GROUP 54A - Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the ignition switch.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between ignition switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ST <Vehicles without KOS>
Check power supply line for open/short circuit or damage.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between KOS&OSS-ECU connector terminal STO and engine-ECU connector terminal ST <Vehicles with KOS>
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Perform troubleshooting of OSS System (Refer to GROUP 42B - Troubleshooting, Trouble Symptom Chart ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 40: Starter switch
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 8. Check starter relay itself
  • Starter relay connector check.
  • Check starter relay itself (Refer to GROUP 16 - Starting System, On-vehicle Service, Starter Relay Continuity Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the starter relay.
 
STEP 9. Perform resistance measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Resistance between terminal starter relay earthing line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between starter relay connector terminal and body earth.
    • Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal NTSW and starter relay connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 11. Perform voltage measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Clutch pedal: Depress
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU STRL line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
NO : Go to Step 12.
 
STEP 12. Check clutch interlock switch itself
  • Clutch interlock switch connector check.
  • Check clutch interlock switch (Refer to GROUP 21A - Clutch Pedal, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the clutch interlock switch.
 
STEP 13. Check harness between clutch interlock switch connector terminal and starter relay connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 14. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal STRL and clutch interlock switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 15. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 413: Starter relay
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 16. Perform voltage measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 17.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between battery and starter relay connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 17. Perform voltage measurement at starter connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Clutch pedal: Depress
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal output line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Go to Step 18.
 
STEP 18. Check harness between starter relay connector terminal and starter connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
YES : Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 19. Perform voltage measurement at starter terminal
  • Disconnect terminal, and measure at harness side.
  • Voltage between terminal starter power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 20.
  • Repair or replace the terminal, or check and repair harness between battery and starter terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 20. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the starter.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE STARTER IS IMPOSSIBLE TO OPERATE<4N15-A/T>
Inspection Procedure 4: Starter Impossible (Starter not Operative) <4N15-A/T>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The power source is supplied from the battery to the starter connector terminal.
  • The battery voltage is applied to the starter relay connector terminal.
  • When the ignition switch "ST" signal is input to the engine-ECU connector terminal ST, the engine-ECU connector terminal STRL turns ON the power transistor inside the unit, and makes the current flow into the starter relay connector terminal to turn ON the relay.
  • When the starter relay is turned ON, the current flows into the starter connector terminal from the starter relay connector terminal to drive the starter motor.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The failure could possibly be caused by the malfunction of the starter or starter system circuits.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery.
  • Failed ignition switch. <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Failed KOS&OSS-ECU. <Vehicles with KOS>
  • Failed starter relay.
  • Failed starter motor.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in starter system circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed inhibitor switch.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 40: Starter switch
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU ST line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
NO <Vehicles without KOS> : Go to Step 4.
NO <Vehicles with KOS> : Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 4. Check ignition switch itself <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Ignition switch connector check.
  • Check ignition switch itself (Refer to GROUP 54A - Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the ignition switch.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between ignition switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal ST <Vehicles without KOS>
Check power supply line for open/short circuit or damage.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between KOS&OSS-ECU connector terminal STO and engine-ECU connector terminal ST <Vehicles with KOS>
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Perform troubleshooting of OSS System (Refer to GROUP 42B - Troubleshooting, Trouble Symptom Chart ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 40: Starter switch
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?

  • Starter relay connector check.
  • Check starter relay itself (Refer to GROUP 16 - Starting System, On-vehicle Service, Starter Relay Continuity Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the starter relay.
 
STEP 9. Perform resistance measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Resistance between terminal starter relay earthing line and body earth.
OK: Continuity (2 Ω or less)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between starter relay connector terminal and body earth.
    • Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal NTSW and starter relay connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 11. Perform voltage measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Transmission: "P" or "N" range
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU STRL line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
NO : Go to Step 12.
 
STEP 12. Check inhibitor switch itself
  • Inhibitor switch connector check.
  • Check inhibitor switch itself (Refer to GROUP 23C - On-vehicle Service, Essential Service, Inhibitor Switch Continuity Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the inhibitor switch.
 
STEP 13. Check harness between inhibitor switch connector terminal and starter relay connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 14. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal STRL and inhibitor switch connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.

Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 413: Starter relay
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ST" position)
  • OFF (ignition switch: "ON" position)
Is the check result normal?

Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 16. Perform voltage measurement at starter relay connector
  • Remove the starter relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal starter relay power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 17.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between battery and starter relay connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 17. Perform voltage measurement at starter connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Transmission: "P" or "N" range
  • Ignition switch: "ST" position
  • Voltage between terminal starter relay output line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Go to Step 18.
 
STEP 18. Check harness between starter relay connector terminal and starter connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
YES : Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 19. Perform voltage measurement at starter terminal
  • Disconnect terminal, and measure at harness side.
  • Voltage between terminal starter power supply line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 20.
  • Repair or replace the terminal, or check and repair harness between battery and starter terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 20. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the starter.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > STARTING IMPOSSIBLE (STARTER OPERATIVE BUT NO INITIAL COMBUSTION)<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 5: Starting Impossible (Starter Operative But no Initial Combustion) <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed glow system
  • Timing chain torn
  • Failed crank angle sensor
  • Failed camshaft position sensor
  • Timing chain in out of place
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check timing chain for breakage
Check timing chain for breakage
  • Engine: Cranking
OK: Camshaft rotates
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the timing chain.
 
STEP 4. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 54: Glow (PWM) 0%
  • Item No. 55: Glow (PWM) 50%
  • Item No. 56: Glow (PWM) 100%
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 6.
Check the glow plug system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0381: Glow Plug Open/Short Malfunction ).
 
STEP 6. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging
  • Check fuel filter for clogging
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 9.
 
STEP 9. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 10.
Check end.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 11. Perform output wave pattern measurement at crank angle sensor and camshaft position sensor (Using an oscilloscope)
<Crank angle sensor>
  • Use the special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect crank angle sensor connector, and measure at the pick-up harness.
  • Engine: Cranking
  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU SGT line and body earth.
<Camshaft position sensor>
  • Use the special tool test harness (MB991709) to connect camshaft position sensor connector, and measure at pick-up harness.
  • Engine: Cranking
  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU SGC line and body earth.
OK: The timings on the output wave pattern at the both sensors should be the same as the specification in the inspection procedure using an oscilloscope (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 18.
Go to Step 12.
 
STEP 12. Check crank angle sensor and camshaft position sensor for correct mounting condition
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair.
 
STEP 13. Check timing mark on the timing chain
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Align the timing marks on timing chain.
 
STEP 14. Check camshaft sensing portion
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Replace the inlet camshaft.
 
STEP 15. Replace the crank angle sensor
After replacing the crank angle sensor, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 16.
Check end.
 
STEP 16. Replace the camshaft position sensor
After replacing the camshaft position sensor, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 17.
Check end.
 
STEP 17. Replace the crankshaft sensing ring
After replacing the crankshaft sensing ring, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Check end.
 
STEP 18. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Repair.
 
STEP 19. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 20.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 20. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).

  • Failed battery
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Injector leaking or clogged

  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure limiter valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed glow system
  • Timing chain torn
  • Failed crank angle sensor
  • Failed camshaft position sensor
  • Timing chain in out of place
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low

  • Item No. 56: Glow (PWM) 100%

Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.

  • Engine: Cranking

  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU SGT line and body earth.

  • Engine: Cranking

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > IMPROPER STARTING (LONG TIME TO START)<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 6: Improper Starting (Long Time to Start) <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed glow system
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 54: Glow (PWM) 0%
  • Item No. 55: Glow (PWM) 50%
  • Item No. 56: Glow (PWM) 100%
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 6.
Check the glow plug system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0381: Glow Plug Open/Short Malfunction ).
 
STEP 6. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging.
  • Check fuel filter for clogging.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 9.

After replacing the common rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 10.
Check end.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).

Is the check result normal?

  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).

Replace the engine-ECU.

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > IMPROPER IDLING<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 7: Improper Idling <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used.
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter.
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged.
  • Failed fuel injector.
  • Fuel injection learning failure.
  • Fuel filter clogged.
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged.
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor.
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve).
  • Failed supply pump correction learning.
  • Failed EGR system operation.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in alternator FR terminal circuit.
  • Failed alternator.
  • Failed valve clearance adjustment.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
  • Compression pressure low.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 3.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 3. Check fuel injector identification code
Check injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Injector Identification Code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 17: EGR valve target position
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 5.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 5. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 6. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging.
  • Check fuel filter for clogging.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 9.
 
STEP 9. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 10.
The check is end.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
The check is end.
 
STEP 11. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Repair.
 
STEP 12. Check valve clearance
Check valve clearance (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Valve Clearance Check and Adjustment ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Adjust the valve clearance.
 
STEP 13. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
OK: Engine is changed (becomes unstable)
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 14.
  • Check the fuel injector system of the defective cylinder.
  • (Refer to Code No. P0201: No. 1 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0202: No. 2 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0203: No. 3 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0204: No. 4 injector circuit malfunction )
 
STEP 14. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 15. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal LNBS and alternator connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 16. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the alternator. Then go to Step 17.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 17. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > IMPROPER IDLING<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 7: Improper Idling <4N15>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged.
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel injection learning failure
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure limiter valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed supply pump correction learning
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in alternator FR terminal circuit
  • Failed alternator
  • Failed valve clearance adjustment
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 3.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 3. Check fuel injector identification code
Check injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Injector Identification Code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 17: EGR valve target position
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 5.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 5. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 6. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging.
  • Check fuel filter for clogging.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 9.
 
STEP 9. Replace the fuel pressure sensor
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 10.
The check is end.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
The check is end.
 
STEP 11. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU connector, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idle operation after warm-up
  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
  • Radiator fan: Not operated
  • Voltage between terminal ALTF and body earth.
OK: The voltage increases when the headlamp switch and the rear window defogger switch are turned ON from OFF.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Go to Step 12.
 
STEP 12. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal ALTF and alternator connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 13. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the alternator.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 14. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair.
 
STEP 15. Check valve clearance
Check valve clearance (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Valve Clearance Check and Adjustment <Except MIVEC> or <MIVEC>).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
Adjust the valve clearance.
 
STEP 16. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
OK: Engine is changed (becomes unstable)
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 17.
  • Check the fuel injector system of the defective cylinder.
  • (Refer to Code No. P0201: No. 1 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0202: No. 2 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0203: No. 3 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0204: No. 4 injector circuit malfunction )
 
STEP 17. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 18.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 18. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE ENGINE STALLS WHEN DECELERATING<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 8: The Engine Stalls when Decelerating <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Failed valve clearance adjustment
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Air cleaner clogged
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check idling condition
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Proceed to troubleshooting for improper idling (Refer to ).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check air cleaner
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the air cleaner.
 
STEP 5. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 6. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging.
  • Check fuel filter for clogging.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 11.
Go to Step 9.
 
STEP 9. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 10.
Check end.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 11. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Repair.
 
STEP 12. Check valve clearance
Check valve clearance (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Valve Clearance Check and Adjustment ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Adjust the valve clearance.
 
STEP 13. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 14.
  • Check the fuel injector system of the defective cylinder.
  • (Refer to Code No. P0201: No. 1 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0202: No. 2 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0203: No. 3 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0204: No. 4 injector circuit malfunction )
 
STEP 14. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 15. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).

PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged

  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Failed valve clearance adjustment
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Air cleaner clogged

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > POOR ACCELERATION<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 9: Poor Acceleration <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed supercharging pressure control system
  • Failed turbocharger
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel contaminated with foreign matter
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Fuel line leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Compression pressure low
  • Air cleaner clogged
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check idling condition
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Proceed to troubleshooting for improper idling (Refer to ).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check air cleaner
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the air cleaner.
 
STEP 5. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 6. Check the turbocharging pressure
Check the turbocharging pressure (Refer to GROUP 15 - On-vehicle Service, Turbocharger Supercharging Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. Check fuel supply line
  • Check for fuel leakage and clogging.
  • Check fuel filter for clogging.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair.
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 12.
Go to Step 10.
 
STEP 10. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 11.
Check end.
 
STEP 11. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 12. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 13.
  • Check the fuel injector system of the defective cylinder.
  • (Refer to Code No. P0201: No. 1 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0202: No. 2 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0203: No. 3 injector circuit malfunction )
  • (Refer to Code No. P0204: No. 4 injector circuit malfunction )
 
STEP 13. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 14. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Repair.
 
STEP 15. Check EGR valve itself
  • EGR valve connector check.
  • Check EGR valve itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation Valve (DC Motor) Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 16.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR valve.
 
STEP 16. Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself
Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, EGR Cooler Bypass Actuator Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 17.
Replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
 
STEP 17. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A LARGE AMOUNT OF FUEL CONSUMPTION<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 10: A Large Amount of Fuel Consumption <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Fuel injector leaking
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel injection learning failure
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed turbocharger
  • Failed thermostat
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Air cleaner clogged
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check whether other trouble symptoms are occurring
Are other trouble symptoms occurring?
Inspection chart for trouble symptoms (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check fuel injector identification code
Check fuel injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Injector Identification Code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 5. Small injection quantity learning
Carry out the small injection quantity learning procedure (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Small Injection Quantity Learning Procedure ).
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 6.
Check end.
 
STEP 6. Check the turbocharging pressure
Check the turbocharging pressure (Refer to GROUP 15 - On-vehicle Service, Turbocharger Supercharging Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. Check thermostat
Check thermostat (Refer to GROUP 14 - Thermostat, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the thermostat.
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 12.
Go to Step 10.
 
STEP 10. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 11.
Check end.
 
STEP 11. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 12. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 13. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair.
 
STEP 14. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A LARGE AMOUNT OF FUEL CONSUMPTION<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 10: A Large Amount of Fuel Consumption <4N15>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Fuel injector leaking
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel injection learning failure
  • Fuel filter clogged
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed turbocharger
  • Failed thermostat
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Air cleaner clogged
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check whether other trouble symptoms are occurring
Are other trouble symptoms occurring?
Inspection chart for trouble symptoms (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check fuel injector identification code
Check fuel injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Injector Identification Code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 5. Small injection quantity learning
Carry out the small injection quantity learning procedure (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Small Injection Quantity Learning Procedure ).
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 6.
Check end.
 
STEP 6. Check the turbocharging pressure
Check the turbocharging pressure (Refer to GROUP 15 - On-vehicle Service, Turbocharger Supercharging Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. Check thermostat
Check thermostat (Refer to GROUP 14 - Thermostat, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the thermostat.
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 12.
Go to Step 10.
 
STEP 10. Replace the fuel pressure sensor
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 11.
Check end.
 
STEP 11. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 12. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.

Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair.

Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > KNOCKING, ABNORMAL NOISE
Inspection Procedure 11: Knocking, Abnormal Noise
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Failed valve clearance adjustment
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check idling condition
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Proceed to troubleshooting for improper idling (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 5.
  • Check the injector system of the defective cylinder.
    • (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0201: No. 1 Injector Circuit Malfunction ).
    • (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0202: No. 2 Injector Circuit Malfunction ).
    • (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0203: No. 3 Injector Circuit Malfunction ).
    • (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0204: No. 4 Injector Circuit Malfunction ).
 
STEP 5. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder.
 
STEP 6. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. Check valve clearance
Check valve clearance (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Valve Clearance Check and Adjustment <4N14 and 4N15 (Except MIVEC)> or <4N15 (MIVEC)>).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Adjust the valve clearance.
 
STEP 8. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WHITE SMOKE

PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Compression pressure low
  • Failed engine-ECU

STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?

Go to Step 2.

Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Proceed to troubleshooting for improper idling (Refer to <4N14> or <4N15>).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?

Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair.

Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BLACK SMOKE, STATE OF EXHAUST GAS PURIFICATION DETERIORATED<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 13: Black Smoke, State of Exhaust Gas Purification Deteriorated <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel injection learning failure
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure relief control valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed supply pump correction learning
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Failed glow system
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Failed turbocharger
  • Improper engine oil volume or viscosity
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check idling condition
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Proceed to troubleshooting for improper idling (Refer to ).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 5: Barometric pressure sensor
  • Item No. 6: Manifold absolute pressure sensor
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Item No. 8: EGR gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 9: Accelerator pedal position sensor (main)
  • Item No. 10: Accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)
  • Item No. 16: EGR valve position sensor
  • Item No. 21: Fuel temperature sensor
  • Item No. 43: Intake air temperature sensor
  • Item No. 45: Throttle position sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 4.
Perform the diagnosis code classified check procedure for the sensor that has shown an abnormal data value (Refer to ).
 
STEP 4. Check fuel injector identification code
Check fuel injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Injector Identification Code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 5. Supply pump correction learning
Carry out the supply pump correction learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Supply Pump Correction Learning Procedure ).
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 6.
Check end.
 
STEP 6. Small injection quantity learning
Carry out the small injection quantity learning procedure (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, Small Injection Quantity Learning Procedure ).
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 7.
Check end.
 
STEP 7. Check the using fuel
Check for foreign matters (water, petrol fuel, etc.) in fuel.
Is the specified fuel being used?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the fuel.
 
STEP 8. Check engine oil
Are the oil volume and viscosity normal?
Go to Step 9.
Replenish or change engine oil.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 54: Glow (PWM) 0%
  • Item No. 55: Glow (PWM) 50%
  • Item No. 56: Glow (PWM) 100%
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 10.
Check the glow plug system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0381: Glow Plug Open/Short Malfunction ).
 
STEP 10. Check the EGR cooler bypass control system
Check the EGR cooler bypass control system [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, EGR Cooler Bypass Control System Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
Go to Step 11.
 
STEP 11. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 31: EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve
OK: Operating sound can be heard and the valve vibrates
Is the check result normal?
Check the connection condition of the vacuum hoses which can be removed, loosened, clogged possibly. And then check whether there are no folded and damaged vacuum hoses.
Check the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve circuit (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P2426 , or No. P2427 ).
 
STEP 12. Check the EGR valve it self
  • EGR valve connector check.
  • Check EGR valve itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation Valve (DC Motor) Check ].
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the EGR valve.
 
STEP 13. Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself
Check EGR cooler bypass actuator itself [Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) System <4N14>, EGR Cooler Bypass Actuator Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Replace the EGR cooler bypass actuator.
 
STEP 14. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 19: Suction control valve
OK: The suction control valve of supply pump is driven
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 15.
Check suction control valve system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0003 or No. P0004 ).
 
STEP 15. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data lists (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 63: Rail pressure sensor
  • Item No. 64: Rail pressure target
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 18.
Go to Step 16.
 
STEP 16. Replace the fuel pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve
After replacing the common-rail assembly, re-check the trouble symptoms.
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 17.
Check end.
 
STEP 17. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the supply pump assembly.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 18. Check compression pressure
Check compression pressure (Refer to GROUP 11A - On-vehicle Service, Compression Pressure Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 19.
Repair.
 
STEP 19. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 20.

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BLACK SMOKE, STATE OF EXHAUST GAS PURIFICATION DETERIORATED<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 13: Black Smoke, State of Exhaust Gas Purification Deteriorated <4N15>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Improper fuel used
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Fuel injection learning failure
  • Failed fuel pressure sensor
  • Failed fuel pressure limiter valve
  • Failed supply pump (suction control valve)
  • Failed supply pump correction learning
  • Failed EGR system operation
  • Failed glow system
  • Failed engine-ECU
  • Compression pressure low
  • Failed turbocharger
  • Improper engine oil volume or viscosity
