13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BATTERY RUNDOWN<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 14: Battery Rundown <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The energised state of the alternator field coil is inputted from the alternator connector terminal C to the engine-ECU connector terminal LNBS via the Local Interconnect Network (LIN).
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The failure could possibly be caused by the failed alternator, defective alternator control system and so on.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Open/short circuit in alternator circuit
  • Failed alternator
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal LNBS and alternator connector terminal
Check signal line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check alternator output line
Alternator output line check (Refer to GROUP 16 - Charging System, On-vehicle Service, Alternator Output Line Voltage Drop Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair.
 
STEP 5. Check alternator output current
Alternator output current check (Refer to GROUP 16 - Charging System, On-vehicle Service, Output Current Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair.
 
STEP 6. Check alternator voltage regulator
Alternator voltage regulator check (Refer to GROUP 16 - Charging System, On-vehicle Service, Regulated Voltage Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair.
 
STEP 7. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BATTERY RUNDOWN<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 14: Battery Rundown <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The exciting currents of the alternator field coil are input into the engine-ECU connector terminal ALTL from the alternator connector terminal.
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The failure could possibly be caused by the failed alternator, defective alternator control system and so on.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in alternator L terminal circuit
  • Failed alternator
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at alternator connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU ALTL line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal ALTL and alternator connector terminal
Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > OVERHEATING
Inspection Procedure 15: Overheating
 
 
 
 
COMMENTS ON TROUBLE SYMPTOM
The failure could possibly be caused by the failed engine cooling system, defective cooling fan system, faulty engine coolant temperature sensor and so on.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Insufficient amount or deteriorated quality engine coolant
  • Failed cooling fan system
  • Failed engine coolant temperature sensor
  • Failed thermostat
  • Failed water pump
  • Failed radiator core
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check the cooling fan
Check the cooling fan.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair.
 
STEP 3. Check engine coolant
noteWhen the engine coolant level is too low, check for any section that cases leakage and repair, if necessary.
Check engine coolant (Refer to GROUP 14 - On-vehicle Service, Engine Coolant Leak Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace or fill the engine coolant.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 7: Engine coolant temperature sensor
OK:
  • Engine cold state: At ambient temperature (atmospheric temperature) or equivalent.
  • Engine hot state: At 80 to 120°C
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Check engine coolant temperature sensor system (Refer to Diagnosis code No. P0117 or No. P0118 ).
 
STEP 5. Check thermostat
Check thermostat (Refer to GROUP 14 - Thermostat, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the thermostat.
 
STEP 6. Check water pump
Check water pump.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Replace the water pump.
 
STEP 7. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the radiator.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE-ECU POWER SUPPLY SYSTEM<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 16: Engine-ECU Power Supply System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The battery voltage is applied to the engine control relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal C/R makes the power transistor in the unit be in ON position and makes currents go on the engine control relay coil, and that makes the relay be in ON position.
  • When the engine control relay is in ON position, the battery voltage is supplied to the engine-ECU connector terminal BAT1 and terminal BAT2, the sensor and the actuator from the engine control relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal GNDB, terminal GNDE and terminal SGND is earthing to the vehicle body.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the ignition switch "ON" signal is input into the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU turns ON the engine control relay. This causes battery voltage to be supplied to the engine-ECU, sensor and actuator.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Failed engine control relay
  • Failed ignition switch <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Failed KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine control relay circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in ignition switch (IG1) circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Open circuit or harness damage in engine-ECU earth circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine control relay connector
  • Remove relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal No. 2 (power supply line) and body earth
  • Voltage between terminal No. 3 (power supply line) and body earth
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between battery and engine control relay connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal C/R and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine control relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal C/R
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check engine control relay itself
  • Engine control relay connector check.
  • Engine control relay continuity check (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine control relay.
 
STEP 6. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) and jumper wire, short-circuit engine-ECU connector terminal C/R to the body earth.
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal BAT1, BAT2 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between engine control relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal BAT1, BAT2
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check engine control relay itself
  • Engine control relay connector check.
  • Engine control relay continuity check (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine control relay.
 
STEP 9. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal IGN and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
NO <Vehicles without KOS> : Go to Step 10.
NO <Vehicles with KOS> : Go to Step 11.
 
STEP 10. Check ignition switch itself <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Ignition switch connector check.
  • Check ignition switch itself (Refer to GROUP 54A - Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair the harness between ignition switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal IGN.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the ignition switch.
 
STEP 11. Check IG1 relay itself <Vehicles with KOS>
  • IG1 relay connector check.
  • Check IG1 relay itself (Refer to GROUP 42B - On-vehicle Service, Relay Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair the harness between IG1 relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal IGN.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the IG1 relay.
 
STEP 12. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal GNDB, GNDE, SGND and body earth
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 13. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 14. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 1.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE-ECU POWER SUPPLY SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 16: Engine-ECU Power Supply System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The battery voltage is applied to the engine control relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal C/R makes the power transistor in the unit be in ON position and makes currents go on the engine control relay coil, and that makes the relay be in ON position.
  • When the engine control relay is in ON position, the battery voltage is supplied to the engine-ECU connector terminal BAT1 and terminal BAT2, the sensor and the actuator from the engine control relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal GNDB, terminal GNDE and terminal SGND is earthing to the vehicle body.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the ignition switch "ON" signal is input into the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU turns ON the engine control relay. This causes battery voltage to be supplied to the engine-ECU, sensor and actuator.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed battery
  • Failed engine control relay
  • Failed ignition switch <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Failed KOS&OSS-ECU <Vehicles with KOS>
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine control relay circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in ignition switch (IG1) circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Open circuit or harness damage in engine-ECU earth circuit, or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine control relay connector
  • Remove relay, and measure at relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal No. 2 (power supply line) and body earth
  • Voltage between terminal No. 3 (power supply line) and body earth
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between battery and engine control relay connector terminal.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Voltage between terminal C/R and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between engine control relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal C/R
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check engine control relay itself
  • Engine control relay connector check.
  • Engine control relay continuity check (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine control relay.
 
STEP 6. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Short-circuit engine-ECU connector terminal C/R to the body earth.
  • Voltage between terminal BAT1, BAT2 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Go to Step 7.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between engine control relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal BAT1, BAT2
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check engine control relay itself
  • Engine control relay connector check.
  • Engine control relay continuity check (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 14.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the engine control relay.
 
STEP 9. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal IGN and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 12.
NO <Vehicles without KOS> : Go to Step 10.
NO <Vehicles with KOS> : Go to Step 11.
 
STEP 10. Check ignition switch itself <Vehicles without KOS>
  • Ignition switch connector check.
  • Check ignition switch itself (Refer to GROUP 54A - Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch, Ignition Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair the harness between ignition switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal IGN.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the ignition switch.
 
STEP 11. Check IG1 relay itself <Vehicles with KOS>
  • IG1 relay connector check.
  • Check IG1 relay itself (Refer to GROUP 42B - On-vehicle Service, Relay Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair the harness between IG1 relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal IGN.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the IG1 relay.
 
STEP 12. Check harness between engine-ECU connector terminal GNDB, GNDE, SGND and body earth
Check earthing line for open circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 13.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 13. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 14. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Go to Step 1.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE-ECU BATTERY BACK-UP SYSTEM<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 17: Engine-ECU Battery Back-up System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Backup power source is directly supplied to an engine-ECU connector terminal BACK from a battery.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in battery back-up circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check battery
Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the battery.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal BACK and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal BACK and battery.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between the battery and engine-ECU connector terminal BACK
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE-ECU BATTERY BACK-UP SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 17: Engine-ECU Battery Back-up System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Backup power source is directly supplied to an engine-ECU connector terminal BACK from a battery.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in battery back-up circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU

Check battery (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery, On-vehicle Service, Battery Test ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.

STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Voltage between terminal BACK and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal BACK and battery.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.

Check power supply line for damage.

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A/C COMPRESSOR RELAY SYSTEM<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 18: A/C Compressor Relay System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The battery voltage is applied to the A/C compressor relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R makes the power transistor in the unit be in ON position and makes currents go on the A/C compressor relay coil, and that makes the relay be in ON position.
  • When the A/C compressor is in ON position, the battery voltage is supplied to the A/C compressor connector terminal from the A/C compressor relay assembly connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the A/C switch-ON signal is input to the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU places the A/C compressor relay in the ON position. Accordingly, the battery voltage supplied to the A/C compressor operates the magnet clutch.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
  • Failed A/C compressor relay.
  • Failed A/C compressor clutch assembly.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in A/C compressor relay circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check A/C compressor relay
  • A/C compressor relay connector check.
  • Check A/C compressor relay (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the A/C compressor relay.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at A/C compressor relay connector
  • Remove relay, and measure at the relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal A/C compressor relay power supply lines and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and battery.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal engine-ECU AC/R line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R and A/C compressor relay connector terminal.
    • Check earthing line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at A/C compressor assembly connector
cautionWhen grounding the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Disconnect connector the engine-ECU connector, and use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) and jumper wire to connect engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R and body earth.
  • Voltage between terminal A/C compressor connector output line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and A/C compressor assembly connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and battery.
    • Check power supply line for damage.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between battery and A/C compressor relay connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and A/C compressor assembly connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. M.U.T.-III actuator test
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 4: A/C compressor relay
OK: The A/C compressor clutch makes an audible sound
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the A/C compressor clutch assembly, then go to Step 10.
 
STEP 10. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A/C COMPRESSOR RELAY SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 18: A/C Compressor Relay System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The battery voltage is applied to the A/C compressor relay connector terminal.
  • The engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R makes the power transistor in the unit be in ON position and makes currents go on the A/C compressor relay coil, and that makes the relay be in ON position.
  • When the A/C compressor is in ON position, the battery voltage is supplied to the A/C compressor connector terminal from the A/C compressor relay assembly connector terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the A/C switch ON signal is input to the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU places the A/C compressor relay in the ON position. Accordingly, the battery voltage supplied to the A/C compressor operates the magnet clutch.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSE
  • Failed A/C compressor relay
  • Failed A/C compressor clutch assembly.
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in A/C compressor relay circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check A/C compressor relay
  • A/C compressor relay connector check.
  • Check A/C compressor relay (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the A/C compressor relay.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at A/C compressor relay connector
  • Remove relay, and measure at the relay box side.
  • Voltage between terminal A/C compressor relay power supply lines and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and battery.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Voltage between terminal AC/R and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R and A/C compressor relay connector terminal.
    • Check earthing line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at A/C compressor assembly connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Using a jumper wire, connect engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R and body earth.
  • Voltage between terminal A/C compressor connector output line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and A/C compressor assembly connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/R
Check earthing line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and battery.
    • Check power supply line for damage.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between battery and A/C compressor relay connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between A/C compressor relay connector terminal and A/C compressor assembly connector terminal
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idle operation after warm-up
  • A/C set temperature:
    • Maximum Cool when temperature in cabin is 25°C or more
    • Maximum Hot when temperature in cabin is 25°C or less
  • Voltage between terminal AC/R and body earth.
OK:
  • 1.0 V or less (when A/C is ON)
  • System voltage (when A/C is OFF)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 10. M.U.T.-III actuator test
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 4: A/C compressor relay
OK: The A/C compressor clutch makes an audible sound
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the A/C compressor clutch assembly.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > DEMISTER SWITCH SIGNAL SYSTEM<4N14 (VEHICLES WITH MANUAL A/C)>
Inspection Procedure 19: Demister Switch Signal System <4N14 (Vehicles with Manual A/C)>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Battery voltage is applied to the demister switch connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal FDFO.
 
 
FUNCTION
The engine-ECU uses the blower switch position signal to stop and restart the engine, based on the AS&G system principle.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed demister switch of heater controller assembly
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in defogger switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check the demister switch of the heater control unit
Check the defogger switch (Refer to GROUP 55A - Heater Control Unit, Demister Switch Continuity Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Replace the heater controller assembly.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at heater controller assembly connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal FDFO line and earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between heater controller assembly connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FDFO
Check output line for open circuit and short to earth.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between heater controller assembly connector terminal and body earth
Check earthing line for ope/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between heater controller assembly connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal FDFO
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check the trouble symptom
Check that the demister switch works normally.
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE OIL PRESSURE SWITCH SYSTEM<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 20: Engine Oil Pressure Switch System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Engine oil pressure switch is built into the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor.
  • Battery voltage is applied to the engine oil pressure switch connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal OPSW.
 
 
FUNCTION
Detect the oil pressure conditions and enter the result into the engine-ECU. After starting the engine if the engine oil pressure rises to higher than the given pressure, the engine oil pressure switch turns OFF. Under this condition the engine-ECU sends the command of turning off the oil warning mark to the combination meter via CAN.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine oil pressure and temperature sensor (integrated with engine oil pressure sensor)
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine oil pressure switch circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPSW line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPSW
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 451: Engine oil pressure switch
OK:
  • ON (ignition switch: "ON" position)
  • OFF (Engine: Idle operation)
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor, then go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > ENGINE OIL PRESSURE SWITCH SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 20: Engine Oil Pressure Switch System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Battery voltage is applied to the engine oil pressure switch connector terminal from the engine-ECU connector terminal OPSW.
 
 
FUNCTION
Detect the oil pressure conditions and enter the result into the engine-ECU. After starting the engine if the engine oil pressure rises to higher than the given pressure, the engine oil pressure switch turns OFF. Under this condition the engine-ECU sends the command of turning off the oil warning mark to the combination meter via CAN.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed engine oil pressure switch
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in engine oil pressure switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at engine oil pressure switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU OPSW line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between engine oil pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPSW
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU connector, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idling
  • Voltage between terminal OPSW and body earth.
OK:
  • 1 V or less (ignition switch: ON)
  • System voltage (during idling)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between engine oil pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal OPSW
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the engine oil pressure switch.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > WATER LEVEL SWITCH SYSTEM
Inspection Procedure 21: Water Level Switch System
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • The battery voltage is applied to the water level switch connector terminal from the ignition switch <vehicles without KOS> or IG1 relay <vehicles with KOS>
  • The ON/OFF signal is inputted to the engine-ECU connector terminal WLS from the water level switch output terminal.
 
 
FUNCTION
Detect the amount of water accumulated in the fuel filter and input the information to the engine-ECU. When the water level is higher than the specified value, the water level switch is turned ON. This allows the engine-ECU to send the request signal of the water level warning-display to the combination meter through CAN.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed water level switch
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in water level switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check water level switch itself
  • Water level switch connector check.
  • Check water level switch itself (Refer to GROUP 13B - Fuel Filter, Fuel Filter Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the water level switch.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at water level switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal No. 2 (power supply line) and body earth
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
  • Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between water level switch connector terminal and ignition switch connector terminal <vehicles without KOS> or IG1 relay connector terminal <vehicles with KOS>.
    • Check power supply line for open/short circuit.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between water level switch connector terminal and ignition switch connector terminal <vehicles without KOS> or IG1 relay connector terminal <vehicles with KOS>
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check harness between water level switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal WLS
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 5. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE DPF REGENERATION INTERVAL IS SHORT<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 22: The DPF Regeneration Interval is Short <4N14>
 
 
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Fuel injector leaking or clogged
  • Failed fuel injector
  • Small injection quantity incorrectly learning
  • Failed air flow sensor connector
  • Failed exhaust differential pressure sensor
  • Failed exhaust gas temperature sensor
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III diagnosis code
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the diagnosis code.
Is any diagnosis code set?
Inspection chart for diagnosis code (Refer to ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 117: No. 1 exhaust gas temperature sensor
  • Item No. 118: No. 2 exhaust gas temperature sensor (catalyst temperature)
  • Item No. 119: No. 3 exhaust gas temperature sensor (DPF temperature)
  • Item No. 120: Exhaust differential pressure sensor
Are the check results normal?
Go to Step 3.
Replace a defective sensor(s).
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 114: Air flow sensor
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Replace the air flow sensor.
 
STEP 4. Check fuel injector identification code
Check fuel injector identification code (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Injector Identification code Registration Procedure ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Register the fuel injector ID.
 
STEP 5. M.U.T.-III actuator test
Use M.U.T.-III to perform the actuator test (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
OK: Engine is changed (becomes unstable)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder. After replacing the fuel injector, register the fuel injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
STEP 6. Check fuel injector itself
  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Execute the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Small Injection Quantity Learning Procedure ).
Replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder. After replacing the fuel injector, register the fuel injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > THE DPF REGENERATION INTERVAL IS SHORT<4N15>

  • Item No. 15: Injector No. 1
  • Item No. 16: Injector No. 2
  • Item No. 17: Injector No. 3
  • Item No. 18: Injector No. 4
OK: Engine is changed (becomes unstable)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder. After replacing the fuel injector, register the fuel injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns ).

  • Fuel injector connector check.
  • Check fuel injector itself (Refer to ).
Is the check result normal?
Execute the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Small Injection Quantity Learning Procedure ).
Replace the fuel injector at the failed cylinder. After replacing the fuel injector, register the fuel injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A/C SWITCH SYSTEM<Manual A/C>
Inspection Procedure 23: A/C Switch System <Manual A/C>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
  • Battery voltage is applied from AC/S terminal on the engine-ECU connector through the dual pressure switch to the A/C switch terminal on the heater control panel connector.
  • It is earthed from the A/C switch terminal on the heater control panel connector through the blower switch to vehicle body.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the A/C switch is turned ON and the blower switch is not turned OFF with the dual pressure switch ON conditions satisfied, the A/C switch ON signal is sent to the engine-ECU. The engine-ECU uses this signal to control the A/C compressor relay.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed A/C switch of heater control unit
  • Failed blower switch of heater control unit
  • Failed dual pressure switch
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in A/C switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 25: A/C switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at dual pressure switch
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal AC/S line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between heater control unit connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/S
Check AC/S line for open circuit and short to earth.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check the dual pressure switch
Check the dual pressure switch (Refer to GROUP 55A - On-vehicle Service, Dual Pressure Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the dual pressure switch.
 
STEP 5. Check the A/C switch of the heater control unit
Check the A/C switch (Refer to GROUP 55A - Heater Control Unit, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Replace the heater control unit.
 
STEP 6. Check the blower switch of the heater control unit
Check the blower switch (Refer to GROUP 55A - Heater Control Unit, Inspection ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Replace the heater control unit.
 
STEP 7. Check harness between dual pressure switch connector terminal and heater control panel connector terminal
Check A/C switch signal line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 8. Check harness between heater control panel connector terminal and blower switch connector terminal
Check A/C switch earth line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 9.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 9. Check harness between blower switch connector terminal and body earth
Check earthing line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 10.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 10. Check harness between dual pressure switch terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/S
Check AC/S line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 11.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 11. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 25: A/C switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > A/C SWITCH SYSTEM<Automatic A/C>
Inspection Procedure 23: A/C Switch System <Automatic A/C>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
Battery voltage is applied from AC/S terminal on the engine-ECU connector through the dual pressure switch to the A/C-ECU connector.
 
 
FUNCTION
The A/C switch ON signal is sent from the A/C-ECU to the engine-ECU. The engine-ECU uses this signal to control the A/C compressor relay.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed dual pressure switch
  • Failed heater controller assembly (integrated with A/C-ECU)
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in A/C switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 25: A/C switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at dual pressure switch
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal AC/S line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between heater controller assembly (integrated with A/C-ECU) connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/S
Check AC/S line for open circuit and short to earth.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. Check the dual pressure switch
Check the dual pressure switch (Refer to GROUP 55A - On-vehicle Service, Dual Pressure Switch Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Replace the dual pressure switch.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between dual pressure switch connector terminal and A/C-ECU connector terminal
Check A/C line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between dual pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal AC/S
Check AC/S line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Perform voltage measurement at A/C-ECU connector
Check the voltage at the A/C-ECU (Refer to GROUP 55B -Troubleshooting, Check at A/C-ECU Terminals ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 8.
Replace the heater controller assembly (integrated with A/C-ECU).
 
STEP 8. M.U.T.-III data list
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 25: A/C switch
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BLOWER SWITCH SYSTEM<4N14 (VEHICLES WITH MANUAL A/C)>
Inspection Procedure 24: Blower Switch System <4N14 (Vehicles with Manual A/C)>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The battery voltage is applied to the engine-ECU connector terminal BFAN from the blower switch.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the blower fan is turned ON and the battery voltage is applied to the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU increases the idle speed.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed A/C system
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in blower switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Check harness between blower switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal BFAN
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 2. Check the trouble symptoms
Is the check result normal?
Check A/C system (Refer to GROUP 55A - Troubleshooting, Check Chart for Trouble Symptoms ). Then go to Step 3.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
STEP 3. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > BLOWER SWITCH SYSTEM<4N15 (VEHICLES WITH MANUAL A/C)>
Inspection Procedure 24: Blower Switch System <4N15 (Vehicles with Manual A/C)>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
The battery voltage is applied to the engine-ECU connector terminal BFAN from the blower switch.
 
 
FUNCTION
When the blower fan is turned ON and the battery voltage is applied to the engine-ECU, the engine-ECU increases the idle speed.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed A/C system
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in blower switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idling
  • Voltage between terminal BFAN and body earth.
OK:
  • System voltage (when blower speed selection dial is "3 (MH)" position)
  • 1 V or less (when blower switch is except "3 (MH)" position)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 2.
Check A/C system (Refer to GROUP 55A - Troubleshooting, Check Chart for Trouble Symptoms ).
 
STEP 2. Check harness between blower switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal BFAN
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. Check the trouble symptoms
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > POWER STEERING FLUID PRESSURE SWITCH SYSTEM<4N14>
Inspection Procedure 25: Power Steering Fluid Pressure Switch System <4N14>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
It is detected whether a load is applied on the power steering fluid pump by steering or not, and the signal is inputted to the engine-ECU. When the power steering fluid pressure switch-ON signal (a large load on the power steering fluid pump) is inputted, the engine-ECU provides the idle-up control.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed power steering oil pump assembly (integrated with power steering fluid pressure switch).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in power steering fluid pressure switch circuit or loose connector contact.
  • Failed engine-ECU.
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at power steering fluid pressure switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU P/S line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Check harness between power steering fluid pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal P/S
Check output line for open/short circuit and damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 3. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 75: Power steering fluid pressure switch
OK:
  • ON [Steering wheel turning (engine: idle operation)]
  • OFF [Steering wheel stationary (engine: idle operation)]
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the power steering oil pump assembly (integrated with power steering fluid pressure switch). Then go to Step 4.
 
STEP 4. Check the trouble symptom
Does the trouble symptom persist?
Replace the engine-ECU.
The check is end.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > POWER STEERING FLUID PRESSURE SWITCH SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 25: Power Steering Fluid Pressure Switch System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
It is detected whether a load is applied on the power steering fluid pump by steering or not, and the signal is inputted to the engine-ECU. When the power steering fluid pressure switch ON signal (a large load on the power steering fluid pump) is inputted, the engine-ECU provides the idle-up control.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed power steering oil pump assembly (integrated with power steering fluid pressure switch).
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in power steering fluid pressure switch circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. Perform voltage measurement at power steering fluid pressure switch connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal engine-ECU P/S line and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 5.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal P/S and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 3.
 
STEP 3. Check harness between power steering fluid pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal P/S
Check output line for short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 4. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 75: Power steering fluid pressure switch
OK:
  • ON [Steering wheel turning (engine: idle operation)]
  • OFF [Steering wheel stationary (engine: idle operation)]
Is the check result normal?
Intermittent malfunction (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, How to Cope with Intermittent Malfunctions ).
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
STEP 5. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect engine-ECU harness, and connect special tool power plant ECU check harness (MB992291) to measure at connector for inspection.
  • Engine: Idling
  • Voltage between terminal P/S and body earth.
OK:
  • System voltage (Steering wheel: Stationary)
  • 1 V or less (Steering wheel: Turned)
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Go to Step 6.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between power steering fluid pressure switch connector terminal and engine-ECU connector terminal P/S
Check output line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Replace the power steering oil pump assembly (integrated with power steering fluid pressure switch).
Repair the harness wire.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > PTC HEATER RELAY SYSTEM<4N14 (Vehicles with PTC heater)>
Inspection Procedure 26: PTC Heater Relay System <4N14 (Vehicles with PTC Heater)>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
With the engine and blower motor being operated, if the PTC heater does not operate by setting the heater control to MAX HOT at the engine coolant temperature of 75°C or lower, the PTC heater, PTC heater relay, engine-ECU or its circuit system may be faulty.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed PTC heater
  • Failed PTC heater relay A
  • Failed PTC heater relay B
  • Failed PTC heater relay C
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in PTC heater relay circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 76: PTC heater relay 1
  • Item No. 77: PTC heater relay 2
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) to check the voltage between terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3 and PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal, ignition switch (IG2) connector terminal <vehicles without KOS>, IG2 relay connector terminal <vehicles with KOS>.
 
STEP 3. Check PTC heater relay
  • PTC heater relay connector check.
  • Check PTC heater relay (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the PTC heater relay.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at PTC heater connector
cautionWhen measuring at the engine-ECU connector, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
(1) Disconnect engine-ECU connector.
(2) Connect the special tool inspection harness (MB993015) and jumper wire to the engine-ECU harness side connector terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3.
(3) Connect the terminal of the jumper wire, which is not connected to the connector, to body earth.
(4) Disconnect PTC heater connector, and measure at the harness side.
(5) Ignition switch: "ON" position
(6) Voltage between PTC heater connector power supply line terminal No. 1, 2, 3 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal and PTC heater connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between fusible link and PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check the trouble symptom
Check that the PTC heater works normally.
Is the check result normal?
This diagnosis is complete.
Replace the PTC heater. Then go to Step 8.
 
STEP 8. Check the trouble symptom
Check that the PTC heater works normally.
Is the check result normal?
This diagnosis is complete.
Replace the engine-ECU.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > SYMPTOM PROCEDURES > PTC HEATER RELAY SYSTEM<4N15>
Inspection Procedure 26: PTC Heater Relay System <4N15>
 
 
 
 
OPERATION
With the engine and blower motor being operated, if the PTC heater does not operate by setting the heater control to MAX HOT at the engine coolant temperature of 75°C or lower, the PTC heater, PTC heater relay, engine-ECU or its circuit system may be faulty.
 
 
PROBABLE CAUSES
  • Failed PTC heater
  • Failed PTC heater relay A
  • Failed PTC heater relay B
  • Failed PTC heater relay C
  • Open/short circuit or harness damage in PTC heater relay circuit or loose connector contact
  • Failed engine-ECU
 
 
DIAGNOSIS PROCEDURE
STEP 1. M.U.T.-III data list
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Use M.U.T.-III to check the data list (Refer to ).
  • Item No. 76: PTC heater relay 1
  • Item No. 77: PTC heater relay 2
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Go to Step 2.
 
STEP 2. Perform voltage measurement at engine-ECU connector
  • Disconnect connector, and measure at the harness side.
  • Ignition switch: "ON" position
  • Voltage between terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 3.
Repair or replace the connector, or check and repair harness between engine-ECU connector terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3 and PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal, ignition switch (IG2) connector terminal <vehicles without KOS>, IG2 relay connector terminal <vehicles with KOS>.
 
STEP 3. Check PTC heater relay
  • PTC heater relay connector check.
  • Check PTC heater relay (Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Check ).
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 4.
Repair or replace the connector, or replace the PTC heater relay.
 
STEP 4. Perform voltage measurement at PTC heater connector
(1) Disconnect engine-ECU connector.
(2) Connect the jumper wire to the engine-ECU harness side connector terminal HTR1, HTR2, HTR3.
(3) Connect the terminal of the jumper wire, which is not connected to the connector, to body earth.
(4) Disconnect PTC heater connector, and measure at the harness side.
(5) Ignition switch: "ON" position
(6) Voltage between PTC heater connector power supply line terminal No. 1, 2, 3 and body earth.
OK: System voltage
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Go to Step 5.
 
STEP 5. Check harness between PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal and PTC heater connector terminal
Check output line for open/short circuit.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 6.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 6. Check harness between fusible link and PTC heater relay A, PTC heater relay B, PTC heater relay C connector terminal
Check power supply line for damage.
Is the check result normal?
Go to Step 7.
Repair or replace the connector, or repair the damaged harness wire.
 
STEP 7. Check the trouble symptom
Check that the PTC heater works normally.
Is the check result normal?
This diagnosis is complete.
Replace the PTC heater. Then go to Step 8.
 
STEP 8. Check the trouble symptom
Check that the PTC heater works normally.
Is the check result normal?
This diagnosis is complete.
Replace the engine-ECU.

Before engine warm-up.OFF
556Fuel temperature start condition of Small Quantity LearningEngine warm-up.ON
Before engine warm-up.OFF

559Variable geometry position sensor
  • Engine coolant temperature: 85 to 95°C
  • Lamps and all accessories: OFF
  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
Idling1.0 to 3.5 mm
When engine is suddenly racedIncreases
560*2DPF Regeneration SW IndicatorIgnition switch: "ON" positionWhen DPF regeneration switch indicator lamp is not illuminatedOFF
When DPF regeneration switch indicator lamp is illuminatedON
561*2DPF Regeneration SWIgnition switch: "ON" positionDPF Regeneration switch: OFFOFF
DPF Regeneration switch: ONON
562Oil Bypass SolenoidEngine: Idle operationOFF
  • Engine: 2,000 r/min
  • Engine coolant temperature: 20°C or more
ON
note
  • *1: At an outside temperature of approximately 20°C. When the exhaust gas recirculation valve position sensor is checked at the outside temperature of 20°C or more, the value would be possibly below the opening degree (normal value). Also, the value would be possibly below the opening degree (normal value) under the following conditions:
    • When the volumetric efficiency of the intake air is reduced due to the higher intake air temperature
  • *2: Since the DPF manual regeneration function is not adopted, these items are displayed but their values are always OFF.
 
 
Engine-ECU Monitor Item
  • Items useful for grasping the engine control condition by the engine-ECU are provided in this monitor item section.
  • Values of these monitor items vary greatly depending on marginal difference of measurement conditions, difference of the environment, aged deterioration of vehicles and so on, and it is difficult to show the precise specification values. Therefore, check conditions, display range and movement of values are described.
Item No.Inspection itemExplanation of M.U.T. displayGuideline for inspectionDisplay range, numerical value
13Accelerator pedal position sensor (main) learned closed positionLearning value of not depressed accelerator pedal state is shown.Ignition switch: "ON"900 to 1,100 mV
46Throttle position sensor learned closed positionLearning value of fully closed throttle valve state is shown.Ignition switch: "ON"9 deg or less

  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
3 to 10 mm3/st

  • Lamps and all accessories: OFF
  • Transmission: Neutral <M/T> or "P" range <A/T>
0.5 to 3 mm3/st

116Request of mode DPF regeneration
  • Indicates the DPF regeneration request mode.
Not request: Not reached to the load amount which requires the regeneration
Distance1: State in which the regeneration is required by the actual driving distance
Distance2: State in which the regeneration is required by the distance calculated by subtracting the distance on the natural regeneration during driving from the actual driving distance
Summ: State in which the regeneration is required by the load amount calculated by the quantity survey
Pressure difference: State in which the regeneration is required by the load amount calculated by the difference pressure
Manual: State in which the regeneration is forcibly performed by the M.U.T.-III.
Ignition switch: "ON"Changes depending on the vehicle status.

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > ACTUATOR TEST REFERENCE TABLE
ACTUATOR TEST REFERENCE TABLE
Item No.Check itemDrive contentsInspection conditionsValue to be determined as normal
1Engine warning lampTurn the engine warning lamp ONIgnition switch: "ON"The engine warning lamp turns ON.
2Glow lampTurn the glow lamp ONIgnition switch: "ON"The glow lamp turns on.
4A/C compressor relayTurning the relay from OFF to ONIgnition switch: "ON"The A/C compressor clutch makes an audible sound.
5Condenser fan relayIs not applicable for this engine, therefore this item is not used for the check.
15Injector No. 1Cut off No. 1 injectorEngine: IdlingEngine is changed (becomes unstable)
16Injector No. 2Cut off No. 2 injectorEngine: IdlingEngine is changed (becomes unstable)
17Injector No. 3Cut off No. 3 injectorEngine: IdlingEngine is changed (becomes unstable)
18Injector No. 4Cut off No. 4 injectorEngine: IdlingEngine is changed (becomes unstable)
19Suction control valveTurn the suction control valve from OFF to ONIgnition switch: "ON"The suction control valve of supply pump is driven.
25EGR valve 0%Lift position reaches 0%Engine: IdlingEGR valve lift is driven into 0% position.
26EGR valve 50%Lift position reaches 50%Engine: IdlingEGR valve lift is driven into 50% position.
27EGR valve 100%Lift position reaches 100%Engine: IdlingEGR valve lift is driven into 100% position.
28Throttle valve 0 degThrottle valve is 0 deg open.Ignition switch: "ON"Throttle valve is driven into 0 deg position.
29Throttle valve 45 degThrottle valve is 45 deg open.Ignition switch: "ON"Throttle valve is driven into 45 deg position.
30Throttle valve 90 degThrottle valve is 90 deg open.Ignition switch: "ON"Throttle valve is driven into 90 deg position.
32EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valveTurn the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve from OFF to ON
  • Ignition switch: "ON"
  • Select ON from the menu.
  • When the engine coolant temperature: 60°C or more
EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve is driven.
Turn the EGR cooler bypass control solenoid valve to OFF
  • Ignition switch: "ON"
  • Select OFF from the menu.
Operating noise is not heard.
36Variable geometry control solenoid valveTurn the variable geometry control solenoid valve from OFF to ONEngine: IdlingVariable geometry actuator is operated.
44DPF warning markShow the DPF warning mark.Ignition switch: "ON"Show the DPF warning mark.
51Oil feeder control valve <4N15>Oil feeder control valve is turned ON from OFF.Ignition switch: "ON"Operating noise is heard.
54Glow (PWM) 0%Duty ratio of current continuity is 0%.Ignition switch: "ON"Electrical current is applied to glow plug at duty ratio of 0%.
55Glow (PWM) 50%Duty ratio of current continuity is 50%.Ignition switch: "ON"Electrical current is applied to glow plug at duty ratio of 50%.
56Glow (PWM) 100%Duty ratio of current continuity is 100%.Ignition switch: "ON"Electrical current is applied to glow plug at duty ratio of 100%.
60Idle up controlIs not applicable for this engine, therefore this item is not used for the check.
61Oil bypass valveTurn the oil bypass valve from OFF to ONIgnition switch: "ON"Operating noise is heard.
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > CHECK AT THE ENGINE-ECU TERMINALS<4N14>

note*: The average voltage is shown when an analogue voltmeter is used (because the average voltage might not be shown stably when digital voltmeter is used).
 
 
CHECK CHART FOR RESISTANCE AND CONTINUITY BETWEEN TERMINALS
1. Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
2. Disconnect the engine-ECU connector.
cautionWhen measuring the engine-ECU connector small terminals, use the special tool inspection harness (MB993015).
3. Use special tools inspection harness (MB993015), Harness set (MB991223) and Extra fine probe (MB992006) to measure the resistance and check for continuity between the terminals of the engine-ECU harness-side connector while referring to the check chart.
note
  1. When measuring resistance and checking continuity, a harness for checking contact pin pressure should be used instead of inserting a test probe.
  2. The chart procedures do not have the particular order.
cautionIf the terminals that should be checked are mistaken, or if connector terminals are not correctly shorted to body earth, damage may be caused to the vehicle wiring, sensors, engine-ECU and/or ohmmeter. Be careful to prevent this!
4. If the ohmmeter shows any deviation from the standard value, check the corresponding sensor, actuator and related electrical wiring, and the repair or replace.
5. After repair or replacement, recheck with the ohmmeter to confirm that the repair or replacement has corrected the problem.
Terminal No.Terminal codeInspection itemNormal condition (Check condition)
1 - 2I/B1 - INJ1No. 1 injectorApproximately 0.59 Ω (at 20°C)
3 - 31INJ4 - I/B4No. 4 injector
6 - 7FRSB - FRSFuel pressure relief control valveApproximately 0.47 Ω (at 20°C)
8 - 40INJ3 - I/B3No. 3 injectorApproximately 0.59 Ω (at 20°C)
9 - 10INJ2 - I/B2No. 2 injector
14 - 15SCV+ - SCV-Suction control valveApproximately 2 Ω (at 20°C)
18 - 19EGR+ - EGR-EGR valve1 to 4 Ω (at 20°C)
20 - 21ETV+ - ETV-Throttle valve control servo0.3 to 100 Ω (at 20°C)
43 - 149VGT - BAT1Variable geometry control solenoid valve10 to 14 Ω (at 20°C)
44 - Body earthGNDE - Body earthEngine-ECU earthContinuity (2 Ω or less)
45 - Body earthGNDB - Body earth

11.7 to 13.2 kΩ (at 20°C)

2.3 to 2.6 kΩ (at 60°C)
1.2 to 1.3 kΩ (at 80°C)
0.63 to 0.72 kΩ (at 100°C)
0.22 to 0.25 kΩ (at 120°C)
0.22 to 0.25 kΩ (at 140°C)

161 - Body earthSGND - Body earthEngine-ECU earthContinuity (2 Ω or less)

0.493 to 0.667 kΩ (at 60°C)
noteThe value in [ ] listed on the normal condition column shows the reference value.
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > CHECK AT THE ENGINE-ECU TERMINALS<4N15>
CHECK AT THE ENGINE-ECU TERMINALS <4N15>
 
 
TERMINAL VOLTAGE CHECK CHART
warningA high-tension voltage is flowing between the engine-ECU and the injectors while the engine is running. Handle them carefully to avoid receiving electric shocks from the voltage.
1. Disconnect the engine-ECU connectors, and connect check harness special tool MB992291 between the engine-ECU connectors.
2. Measure the voltage between each check harness connector terminal and check harness connector earth terminal (GNDB, GNDE or SGND).
3. Connect a needle-nosed wire probe to a voltmeter probe.
4. Referring to the check sheet, insert the micromini probe into the check harness connector and measure the voltage.
note
  • You may find it convenient to pull out the engine-ECU to make it easier to reach the connector terminals.
  • The chart procedures do not have the particular order.
cautionShort-circuiting the positive (+) probe between a connector terminal and earth could damage the vehicle wiring, the sensor, engine-ECU or all of them. Be careful to prevent this!
5. If voltmeter shows any deviation from standard value, check the corresponding sensor, actuator and related electrical wiring, then repair or replace.
6. After repair or replacement, recheck with the voltmeter to confirm that the repair has corrected the problem.

Engine-ECU Connector Terminal Arrangement
Terminal No.Terminal codeCheck itemInspection condition (engine status)Normal condition:

Engine: Idle operation1 V or less

(after warning up)

(A/C compressor in operation)
