  • Ignition switch: "ON"
  • Blower switch: ON
Except demister position1 V or less
Demister positionSystem voltage
131SCV+Suction control valve (+)Engine: Idle operation5 - 6 V*1
Engine: AccelerationVoltage decreases
134AP5Power supply voltage applied to accelerator pedal position sensor (sub)Ignition switch: "ON"4.9 to 5.1 V
135APSSAccelerator pedal position sensor (sub)Ignition switch: "ON"Release the accelerator pedalSystem voltage
Depress the accelerator pedal fully2,000 mV or more <Vehicles without speed limiter>
2,100 mV or more <Vehicles with speed limiter>
140AFSAir flow sensorEngine: Gradually increase the speedVoltage increases
141ALTFAlternator FR terminal
  • Engine: Idle operation after warm-up
  • Radiator fan: Non-operation
  • Headlamp switch: OFF → ON
  • Stop lamp: OFF → ON
  • Rear defogger switch: OFF → ON
Voltage decreases
148ECB5Power supply voltage applied to battery current sensorIgnition switch: "ON"4.9 to 5.1 V
149APS5Power supply voltage applied to accelerator pedal position sensor (main)Ignition switch: "ON"4.9 to 5.1 V
150APSMAccelerator pedal position sensor (main)Ignition switch: "ON"Release the accelerator pedalSystem voltage
Depress the accelerator pedal fully4,000 mV or more <Vehicles without speed limiter>
4,400 mV or more <Vehicles with speed limiter>
note*1: The average voltage is shown when an analogue voltmeter is used (because the average voltage might not be shown stably when digital voltmeter is used).
 
 
CHECK CHART FOR RESISTANCE AND CONTINUITY BETWEEN TERMINALS
1. Turn the ignition switch to "LOCK" (OFF) position.
2. Disconnect the engine-ECU connector.
3. Measure the resistance and check for continuity between the terminals of the engine-ECU harness-side connector while referring to the check chart.
note
  • When measuring resistance and checking continuity, a harness for checking contact pin pressure should be used instead of inserting a test probe.
  • The chart procedures do not have the particular order.
cautionIf the terminals that should be checked are mistaken, or if connector terminals are not correctly shorted to earth, damage may be caused to the vehicle wiring, sensors, engine-ECU and/or ohmmeter. Be careful to prevent this!
4. If the ohmmeter shows any deviation from the standard value, check the corresponding sensor, actuator and related electrical wiring, and the repair or replace.
5. After repair or replacement, recheck with the ohmmeter to confirm that the repair or replacement has corrected the problem.

Terminal No.Terminal codeInspection itemNormal condition (Check condition)
1 - 2I/B1 - INJ1No. 1 injectorApproximately 0.45 Ω (at 20°C)
73 - 75I/B2 - INJ2No. 2 injector
49 - 50I/B3 - INJ3No. 3 injector
25 - 27I/B4 - INJ4No. 4 injector

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > INSPECTION PROCEDURE USING AN OSCILLOSCOPE<4N14>
INSPECTION PROCEDURE USING OSCILLOSCOPE <4N14>
cautionSince the engine-ECU cannot be backprobed, measure at the camshaft position sensor, crank angle sensor and suction control valve side when inspecting with oscilloscope.
The output signals of the sensors and the conditions of the actuation signals of the actuators can be inspected visually by observing the waveforms on the oscilloscope.
 
 
CAMSHAFT POSITION SENSOR AND CRANK ANGLE SENSOR
 
 
Measurement Method
1. Disconnect the camshaft position sensor connector and connect special tool test harness (MB991709) in between (All terminals should be connected).
2. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to camshaft position sensor terminal No. 2.
3. Disconnect the crank angle sensor connector and connect special tool test harness (MB991709) in between (All terminals should be connected).
4. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to crank angle sensor terminal No. 3.
 
 
 
Standard Wave Pattern
 
Observation conditions
FunctionSpecial patterns
Pattern heightLow
Pattern selectorDisplay
Engine speedIdle
 
 
 
Wave Pattern Observation Points
Verify that the sensor signal frequency increases as the engine speed rises.
 
 
 
Examples of Abnormal Wave Patterns
  • Example 1
  • Wave pattern characteristics
    • Rectangular wave pattern is output even when the engine is not started.
  • Cause of problem
    • Sensor interface malfunction
  • Example 2
  • Wave pattern characteristics
    • Wave pattern is displaced to the left or right.
  • Cause of problem
    • Loose timing belt
    • Abnormality in sensor disk
 
 
 
 
SUCTION CONTROL VALVE
 
 
Measurement Method
1. Disconnect the suction control valve connector, and then connect special tool test harness (MB991658) in between (All terminals should be connected).
2. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to terminal No. 1, of the suction control valve connector.
 
 
 
Standard Wave Pattern
 
Observation conditions
FunctionSpecial patterns
Pattern heightVariable
Variable knobAdjust while viewing the wave pattern
Pattern selectorDisplay
EngineIdle
 
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > TROUBLESHOOTING > INSPECTION PROCEDURE USING AN OSCILLOSCOPE<4N15>
INSPECTION PROCEDURE USING OSCILLOSCOPE <4N15>
The output signals of the sensors and the conditions of the actuation signals of the actuators can be inspected visually by observing the waveforms on the oscilloscope.
 
 
CAMSHAFT POSITION SENSOR AND CRANK ANGLE SENSOR
 
 
Measurement Method
1. Disconnect the camshaft position sensor connector and connect the special tool test harness (MB991709) in between (All terminals should be connected).
2. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to camshaft position sensor terminal No. 2.
3. Disconnect the crank angle sensor connector and connect the special tool test harness (MB991709) in between (All terminals should be connected).
4. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to crank angle sensor terminal No. 3.
 
 
 
Alternate Method (Test harness not available)
1. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to engine-ECU terminal SGC (When checking the camshaft position sensor signal wave pattern.)
2. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to engine-ECU terminal SGT (When checking the crank angle sensor signal wave pattern.)
 

 
 
Standard Wave Pattern
 
Observation conditions
FunctionSpecial patterns
Pattern heightLow
Pattern selectorDisplay
Engine speedIdle

 
 
 
Wave Pattern Observation Points
  • Verify that the sensor signal frequency increases as the engine speed rises.
 
 
 
Examples of Abnormal Wave Patterns
  • Example 1
  • Wave pattern characteristics
    • Rectangular wave pattern is output even when the engine is not started.
  • Cause of problem
    • Sensor interface malfunction
  • Example 2
  • Wave pattern characteristics
    • Wave pattern is displaced to the left or right.
  • Cause of problem
    • Loose timing belt
    • Abnormality in sensor disk
 
 
 
 
SUCTION CONTROL VALVE
 
 
Measurement Method
1. Disconnect the suction control valve connector, and then connect the special tool test harness (MB991658) in between (All terminals should be connected).
2. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to terminal No. 1, of the suction control valve connector.
 
 
 
Alternate Method (Test harness not available)
1. Connect the oscilloscope special pattern pickup to engine-ECU terminal SCV+.
 

 
 
Standard Wave Pattern
 
Observation conditions
FunctionSpecial patterns
Pattern heightVariable
Variable knobAdjust while viewing the wave pattern
Pattern selectorDisplay
EngineIdle
 
 
 
Wave Pattern Observation Points
When fuel pressure rises while the engine load is high, the driving time of the suction control valve becomes short.
 
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > EVACUATION OF WATER FROM FUEL FILTER
EVACUATION OF WATER FROM FUEL FILTER
When the water is accumulated in the fuel filter cartridge and the fuel filter indicator is displayed on the combination meter, drain the water according to the procedure below.
1. Loosen the drain plug.
2. After water is evacuated, tighten the drain plug.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > FUEL LINE AIR-BLEEDING
FUEL LINE AIR-BLEEDING
When the following service work(s) is done, refill the fuel and then evacuate air from the fuel line.
  • Fuel hose or pipe is removed
  • Fuel filter is replaced
  • Fuel injector assembly is removed
  • If necessary for access, fuel is drained from the fuel tank.
Repeat until the hand pump operation becomes stiff.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > FUEL FILTER CARTRIDGE REPLACEMENT
FUEL FILTER REPLACEMENT
 
 
Refer to GROUP 13B - Fuel Filter .
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > FUEL LINE LEAK CHECK
FUEL LINE LEAK CHECK
1.
cautionTo prevent damage to the M.U.T.-III, always turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position before connecting or disconnecting the M.U.T.-III.
Connect the M.U.T.-III to the diagnosis connector.
2. Start the engine, and let it run at idle.
3. Select "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" from "System select Screen" of the M.U.T.-III.
4. Select "Special Function" from "MPI/GDI/DIESEL" Screen.
5. Select "Fuel leakage check" from "Test Screen". Carry out the fuel leakage check 5 times in a row.
noteDuring the test, the engine speed and the fuel pressure is 2, 000 r/min and 180Mpa for 20 seconds respectively.
6. Turn the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position, and stop the engine.
7. Disconnecting the M.U.T.-III is the reverse of the connecting sequence.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > COMPONENT LOCATION<4N14>

13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > ENGINE CONTROL RELAY CONTINUITY CHECK
ENGINE CONTROL RELAY CONTINUITY CHECK
Refer to GROUP 00 - How to Use Troubleshooting/Inspection Service Points, Relay Check .
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > ENGINE COOLANT TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
ENGINE COOLANT TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
1.
cautionDo not tilt the special tool engine coolant temperature sensor wrench (MB992042) as the engine coolant temperature sensor connector may be damaged.
Remove the engine coolant temperature sensor using the special tool engine coolant temperature sensor wrench (MB992042).
2. With temperature sensing portion of engine coolant temperature sensor immersed in hot water, check resistance.
Standard value:
  • 14 to 17 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • [5.1 to 6.5 kΩ (at 0°C)]
  • 2.1 to 2.7 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • [0.9 to 1.3 kΩ (at 40°C)]
  • [0.48 to 0.68 kΩ (at 60°C)]
  • [0.26 to 0.36 kΩ (at 80°C)]
note[ ]: Reference value.
3. If the resistance deviates from the standard value greatly, replace the sensor.
4. Apply the sealant over the screw sections on the engine coolant temperature sensor.
Specified sealant:
  • ThreeBond 1324N or equivalent
5. Tighten the engine coolant temperature sensor to the specified torque, using special tool engine coolant temperature sensor wrench (MB992042).
Tightening torque: 30 ± 9 N·m
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > ENGINE OIL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK<4N14>
ENGINE OIL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK <4N14>
1.
cautionDo not tilt the special tool oil pressure sensor wrench (MB992118) as the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor connector may be damaged.
Use special tool oil pressure switch wrench (MB992118) to remove the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor.
2. With temperature sensing portion of engine oil pressure and temperature sensor immersed in hot engine oil, check the resistance between terminal No. 3 and No.4.
Standard value:
  • 91.3 to 106.0 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • 30.7 to 34.9 kΩ (at 0°C)
  • 11.7 to 13.2 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • 5.0 to 5.6 kΩ (at 40°C)
  • 2.3 to 2.6 kΩ (at 60°C)
  • 1.2 to 1.3 kΩ (at 80°C)
  • 0.64 to 0.72 kΩ (at 100°C)
  • 0.37 to 0.41 kΩ (at 120°C)
  • 0.22 to 0.25 kΩ (at 140°C)
3. If the resistance deviates from the standard value greatly, replace the sensor.
4.
caution
  • Do not reuse the O-ring.
  • Install the O-ring after wrap a tape not having adhesion (such as a seal tape) round the notch on the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor to prevent it from damage. The damaged O-ring may cause oil leakage.
Install the O-ring to the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor.
5.
cautionTo install the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor, be careful to keep foreign material from entering oil channels.
Wipe off the dirt on the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor and engine oil pressure and temperature sensor mounting surface.
6. Apply a little amount of engine oil to the O-ring.
7. Install the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor to the connector.
8. In the same manner as removal, use special tool oil pressure switch wrench (MB992118) to tighten the engine oil pressure and temperature sensor to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 4 N·m
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > INJECTOR CHECK<4N14>
FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY CHECK <4N14>
1. Disconnect the fuel injector assembly connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: Approximately 0.59 Ω (at 20°C)
3. Check the continuity between terminal No. 1 and injector body, terminal No.2 and injector body (check short to earth in the internal circuit of the fuel injector assembly).
Standard value: No continuity
4. If not within the standard value, replace the fuel injector assembly. After replacing the fuel injector assembly, register the injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > INJECTOR CHECK<4N15>
FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY CHECK <4N15>
1. Disconnect the fuel injector assembly connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: Approximately 0.45 Ω (at 20°C)
3. If not within the standard value, replace the fuel injector assembly. After replacing the fuel injector assembly, register the fuel injector identification code and learn fuel injection (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > INTAKE AIR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK<4N14>
INTAKE AIR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK <4N14>
1. Disconnect the air flow sensor connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 3.
Standard value:
  • 13.6 to 18.4 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • 2.21 to 2.69 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • 0.493 to 0.667 kΩ (at 60°C)
3. Remove the air flow sensor.
4. Measure the resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
Temperature (°C)Resistance (kΩ)
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the air flow sensor.
6. Install the air flow sensor and tighten it to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 1.0 ± 0.1 N·m
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > INTAKE AIR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK<4N15>
INTAKE AIR TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK <4N15>
1. Disconnect the air flow sensor connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 4 and No. 5.
Standard value:
  • 13 to 19 kΩ (at -20°C)
  • [4.8 to 7.0 kΩ (at 0°C)]
  • 2.1 to 2.8 kΩ (at 20°C)
  • [0.9 to 1.5 kΩ (at 40°C)]
  • 0.47 to 0.69 kΩ (at 60°C)
  • [0.27 to 0.39 kΩ (at 80°C)]
note[ ]: Reference value.
3. Remove the air flow sensor.
4. Measure the resistance while heating the sensor using a hair drier.
Normal condition:
 
Temperature (°C)Resistance (kΩ)
HigherSmaller
5. If the value deviates from the standard value or the resistance remains unchanged, replace the air flow sensor.
6. Install the air flow sensor and tighten it to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 1.0 ± 0.1 N·m
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > SUCTION CONTROL VALVE CHECK
SUCTION CONTROL VALVE CHECK
1. Disconnect the suction control valve connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2
Standard value: Approximately 2.1 Ω (at 20 °C)
3. If not within the standard value, replace the suction control valve. After replacing the suction control valve, learn the supply pump (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > FUEL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
FUEL TEMPERATURE SENSOR CHECK
1. Disconnect the fuel temperature sensor connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: Approximately 2.0 to 3.0 kΩ (at 20 °C)
3. If not within the standard value, replace the supply pump assembly. After replacing the supply pump, learn the supply pump (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Learns ).
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > COMMON RAIL CHECK
COMMON RAIL ASSEMBLY CHECK
cautionHigh pressure fuel is supplied to the common rail assembly. It is dangerous to remove the rail pressure sensor and fuel pressure relief control valve from the common rail assembly because it may cause fuel leaks. Do not remove the rail pressure sensor and fuel pressure relief control valve from the common rail assembly.
1. Visually check the common rail assembly for cracks, damage, and corrosion.
2. If an abnormality is found, replace the common rail assembly.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > FUEL PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE CHECK<4N14>
FUEL PRESSURE RELIEF CONTROL VALVE CHECK <4N14>
cautionHigh pressure fuel is supplied to the common rail assembly. It is dangerous to remove the fuel pressure relief control valve from the common rail assembly because it may cause fuel leaks. Do not remove the fuel pressure relief control valve from the common rail assembly.
1. Disconnect the fuel pressure relief control valve connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: Approximately 0.47 Ω (at 20°C)
3. Check the continuity between terminal No. 1 and fuel pressure relief control valve body, terminal No.2 and fuel pressure relief control valve body (check short to earth in the internal circuit of the fuel pressure relief control valve).
Standard value: No continuity
4. If not within the standard value, replace the common rail assembly (integrated with fuel pressure relief control valve).
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > THROTTLE VALVE CONTROL SERVO CHECK
THROTTLE VALVE CONTROL SERVO CHECK
 
 
Operation Check
1. Start up the engine and run at idle speed.
2. When turning the ignition switch to the "LOCK" (OFF) position and stopping the engine, check that the operating sound of the throttle valve control servo is heard from the throttle body: the short "wheeen" sound is heard.
3. If the operating sound is not heard, check the drive circuit of the throttle valve control servo.
noteIf the circuit is normal and the operating sound is not heard, it could possibly be caused by the failed throttle body assembly.
 
 
 
Coil Resistance Check
1. Disconnect the throttle body assembly connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 5 and No. 6.
Standard value: 0.3 to 100 Ω (at 20 °C)
noteIf the measured resistance deviates from the standard value, fully close the throttle valve with your finger more than five times, then check the result again.
If the throttle valve control serve is not used for an extended period of time, the resistance may be increased as a result of internal forming of oxide film. Therefore, it means that the oxide film can be removed through a self cleaning capability of the throttle valve control servo, if forcibly moved.
3. If the resistance deviates from outside the standard value, replace the throttle body assembly.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ON-VEHICLE SERVICE > OIL FEEDER CONTROL VALVE CHECK<4N15 (MIVEC)>
OIL FEEDER CONTROL VALVE CHECK <4N15 (MIVEC)>
 
 
Operation Check
 
 
1. Disconnect the oil feeder control valve connector.
2.
cautionTo prevent the coil from burning, keep the duration of the voltage application as short as possible.
Make sure that the oil feeder control valve generates a tick sound when the battery voltage is applied between the connector terminals at the oil feeder control valve side.
 
 
 
 
Coil Resistance Check
1. Disconnect the oil feeder control valve connector.
2. Measure the resistance between terminal No. 1 and No. 2.
Standard value: 6.9 to 7.9 Ω (at 20°C)
3. If the resistance deviates from the standard value, replace the oil feeder control valve.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > FUEL INJECTOR > FUEL INJECTOR REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N14>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N14>
 
 
cautionWhen the fuel injector assembly is replaced, register the fuel injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator and Injector Lower Insulator Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Fuel Line Leak Check (Refer to )
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator and Injector Lower Insulator Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Removal steps
1.Control wiring harness
2.Harness bracket
>>A<<3.Fuel injection pipe No.1
>>A<<4.Fuel injection pipe No.2
>>A<<5.Fuel injection pipe No.3
>>A<<6.Fuel injection pipe No.4
7.Fuel return line hose D
8.Eye bolt
9.Fuel leakage pipe assembly
10.Fuel return gasket
<<A>>>>A<<11.Fuel injector assembly
>>A<<12.Fuel injector washer
>>A<<13.Fuel injector holder
<<B>>>>A<<14.Fuel injector nozzle gasket
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINTS
 
 
<<A>> FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
cautionAlways reinstall the fuel injector assembly to the cylinder from which it has been removed.
 
 
<<B>> FUEL INJECTOR NOZZLE GASKET REMOVAL
1. Insert special tool nozzle gasket remover (MB992333) to the fuel injector assembly mounting hole on the cylinder head.
2. Rotate the dial of the tool as shown, and then pull out the tool while holding the fuel injector nozzle gasket.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< FUEL INJECTOR NOZZLE GASKET/FUEL INJECTOR HOLDER/FUEL INJECTOR WASHER/FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.4/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.3/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.2/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.1 INSTALLATION
1. Clean the fuel injector assembly (nozzle) and the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) by following the procedure below.
(1)
cautionDo not clean the injection part of the nozzle with a resin spatula.
Using a resin spatula, scrape off the carbon deposit on the fuel injector nozzle side face ("A" shown in the figure).
(2) Spray the carburettor cleaner (MZ100139) or equivalent to the nozzle side face ("A" shown in the figure).
(3)
cautionDo not touch the injection part of the nozzle with hand or wipe it with a rag.
Leave the injection part for a while until the carbon deposit melts down, and then blow air to the injection part.
(4) Insert special tool ornament remover (MB990784) to the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) with turning the special tool as shown, and scrape off the carbon deposit.
(5)
cautionIn order to prevent carbon from adhering to the inner surface of the cylinder, blow air with the piston in the TDC position.
Remove special tool MB990784, and blow off the carbon deposit on the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) by air.
(6) Check that there is no carbon deposit remaining on the contact surface of the fuel injector nozzle gasket.
noteRepeat Step 4 to Step 6 several times until the carbon deposit is completely removed.
2. Replace the fuel injector nozzle gasket with a new one.
3. Install the fuel injector holder to the fuel injector assembly from the bottom side of the fuel injector assembly, and slide the fuel injector holder to align the protrusion part of the fuel injector holder hole for the fuel injector assembly installation with the groove of the fuel injector assembly.
4.
caution
  • If the removed fuel injector assembly to be reinstalled cannot be identified, register the fuel injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning. (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
  • Securely insert the fuel injector assembly to the cylinder head.
Install the fuel injector and fuel injector holder assembly.
5. Replace the fuel injector washer with a new one.
6. Apply an adequate and minimum amount of engine oil to the thread of the fuel injector holder bolts, the lower area of the flange, and fuel injector washer.
7. Let both front and rear sides of the fuel injector holder bolts be seated at the same time.
8.
cautionDo not directly put a steel scale on the sealed surface of the fuel leakage pipe assembly located on the upper side of the fuel injector assembly. Put the steel scale while avoiding contact with the sealed surface. Otherwise, it may cause seal malfunction.
Put the steel scale on the upper flat part of the fuel injector assembly to make horizontal axis as shown in the illustration.
9. Measure the height of fuel injector holder bolts located on the front and rear side of fuel injector holder against the horizontal axis, then check that the difference of the measured values is within 2 mm.
noteIt is not necessary to adjust all the fuel injector holder bolts to be the same height. Each 2 bolts of fuel injector assembly need to be the same height.
10. Mount the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 and temporarily install them.
11. Tighten the bolt on the engine front side of the fuel injector holder bolts to 1.2 ± 0.2 N·m.
12. Use special tool angle gauge (MB991614) to tighten the engine rear side bolts of the fuel injector holder to 180° ± 1°.
13. Use special tool (MB991614) to tighten the engine front side bolts of the fuel injector holder to 180° ± 1°.
14.
caution
  • The removed fuel injection pipe can be reassembled up to 5 times. To count the number of fuel injection pipe reassembly, record it by adding the reassembly number of this time (once usually) to the previous number of reassembly written on the maintenance handbook. When the number of the previous reassembly reaches 5 or when the fuel injector assembly is replaced, always use a new fuel injection pipe. At that time, write "New (0 times)" in the maintenance handbook.
  • If a fuel leak is present in the fuel injection pipe once, do not reuse it and replace with a new one.
  • If the fuel injector assembly is replaced, the contact surface (seal surface) between the fuel injection pipe and the fuel injector assembly is changed. So do not reuse the fuel injection pipe, and replace with a new one.
  • When reassembling the fuel injection pipe, remove the foreign material attached on the sealing surface, and install it with the contacting point of the pipe aligned.
Loosen the install bolt of the common rail assembly and the flare nut of the supply pump pipe. (Refer to ).
15. Align the fuel injection pipe centre axis with the other side components (common rail assembly and fuel injector assembly) centre axis to install the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4. Then, tighten the flare nut temporarily until the tip of pipe (seal surface) contacts with the other side components.
noteWhen the fuel injection pipe is installed, tighten the flare nut while shaking the pipe lightly to align the centre axis of both components.
16. Useing special tool crowfoot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4 to the temporary tightening torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (18 ± 2) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 18 ± 2: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
17. Using special tool crow foot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4 to the specified torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (35 ± 5) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 35 ± 5: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
18. Tighten the install bolt of the common rail assembly and the flare nut of the supply pump pipe. (Refer to ).
19. Check that no fuel is leaked from the fuel injection pipe connection area and the fuel return gasket.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > FUEL INJECTOR > FUEL INJECTOR REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N15>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N15>
 
 
cautionWhen the fuel injector assembly is replaced, register the fuel injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator and Injector Lower Insulator Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Fuel Line Leak Check (Refer to )
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator and Injector Lower Insulator Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Removal steps
1.Control wiring harness
2.Harness bracket
>>A<<3.Fuel injection pipe No. 1
>>A<<4.Fuel injection pipe No. 2
>>A<<5.Fuel injection pipe No. 3
>>A<<6.Fuel injection pipe No. 4
7.Joint clip
8.Fuel return line hose C and fuel injection tube joint assembly
9.Fuel injection tube joint A
10.Fuel injection tube joint B
11.O-ring
12.Fuel return line hose C
13.Fuel return line hose C connection
>>A<<14.Fuel injector washer
>>A<<15.Fuel injector holder
<<A>>>>A<<16.Fuel injector assembly
<<B>>17.Fuel injector nozzle gasket
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINTS
 
 
<<A>> FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
cautionAlways reinstall the fuel injector assembly to the cylinder from which it has been removed.
 
 
<<B>> FUEL INJECTOR NOZZLE GASKET REMOVAL
1. Insert the special tool nozzle gasket remover (MB992333) to the fuel injector assembly mounting hole on the cylinder head.
2. Rotate the dial of the tool as shown, and then pull out the tool while holding the fuel injector nozzle gasket.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< FUEL INJECTOR ASSEMBLY/FUEL INJECTOR HOLDER/FUEL INJECTOR WASHER/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO. 4/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO. 3/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO. 2/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO. 1 INSTALLATION
1. Clean the fuel injector assembly (nozzle) and the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) by following the procedure below.
(1)
cautionDo not clean the injection part of the nozzle with a resin spatula.
Using a resin spatula, scrape off the carbon deposit on the fuel injector nozzle side face ("A" shown in the figure).
(2) Spray the carburettor cleaner (MITSUBISHI MOTORS GENUINE Part No. MZ100139 or equivalent) to the nozzle side face ("A" shown in the figure).
(3)
cautionDo not touch the injection part of the nozzle with hand or wipe it with a rag.
Leave the injection part for a while until the carbon deposit melts down, and then blow air to the injection part.
(4) Insert the special tool ornament remover (MB990784) to the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) with turning the special tool as shown, and scrape off the carbon deposit.
(5)
cautionIn order to prevent carbon from adhering to the inner surface of the cylinder, blow air with the piston in the TDC position.
Remove the special tool MB990784, and blow off the carbon deposit on the cylinder head (fuel injector assembly mounting hole) by air.
(6) Check that there is no carbon deposit remaining on the contact surface of the fuel injector nozzle gasket.
noteRepeat Step 4 to Step 6 several times until the carbon deposit is completely removed.
2. Replace the fuel injector nozzle gasket with a new one.
3.
caution
  • If the removed fuel injector assembly to be reinstalled cannot be identified, register the fuel injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning. (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
  • Securely insert the fuel injector assembly.
Install the fuel injector assembly.
4. Apply an adequate and minimum amount of engine oil to the thread of the fuel injector holder bolts, the lower area of the flange, and fuel injector washer.
5. Put the steel scale on the upper flat part of the fuel injector assembly to make horizontal axis as shown in the illustration.
6. Measure the height of fuel injector holder bolts located on the front and rear side of fuel injector holder against the horizontal axis, then check that the difference of the measured values is within 2 mm.
noteIt is not necessary to adjust all the fuel injector holder bolts to be the same height. Each 2 bolts of fuel injector assembly need to be the same height.
7. Mount the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 and temporarily install them.
8. Tighten the bolt on the engine front side of the fuel injector holder bolts to 1.1 ± 0.1 N·m.
9. Use the special tool angle gauge (MB991614) to tighten the engine rear side bolts of the fuel injector holder to 180 ± 1 degree angle.
10. Use the special tool MB991614 to tighten the engine front side bolts of the fuel injector holder to 90 ± 1 degree angle.
11.
caution
  • The removed fuel injection pipe can be reassembled up to five times. To count the number of fuel injection pipe reassembly, record it by adding the reassembly number of this time (once usually) to the previous number of reassembly written on the maintenance handbook. When the number of the previous reassembly reaches 5 or when the fuel injector assembly or common rail assembly is replaced, always use a new fuel injection pipe. At that time, write "New (0 times)" in the maintenance handbook.
  • If a fuel leak is present in the fuel injection pipe and fuel injection pipe set once, do not reuse it and replace with a new one.
  • If the fuel injector assembly, common rail assembly or supply pump assembly is replaced, the contact surface (seal surface) between the fuel injection pipe and fuel injection pipe set, and the other side component is changed, do not reuse the fuel injection pipe and fuel supply pump pipe and replace with a new one.
  • When reassembling the fuel injection pipe, remove the foreign material attached on the sealing surface, and install it with the contacting point of the pipe aligned.
Loosen the install bolt of the common rail assembly, and the flare nut of the supply pump pipe (Refer to ).
12. Align the fuel injection pipe centre axis with the other side components (common rail assembly and fuel injector assembly) centre axis to install the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4. Then, tighten the flare nut temporarily until the tip of pipe (seal surface) contacts with the other side components.
noteWhen the fuel injection pipe is installed, tighten the flare nut while shaking the pipe lightly to align the centre axis of both components.
13. Using the special tool crowfoot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 to the temporary tightening torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (18 ± 2) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 18 ± 2: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
14. Using the special tool crow foot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 to the specified torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (35 ± 5) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 35 ± 5: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
15. Tighten the install bolt of the common rail assembly, and the flare nut of the supply pump pipe. (Refer to .)
16. Check that no fuel is leaked from the fuel injection pipe connection area and the gasket.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > COMMON RAIL > COMMON RAIL REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N14>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N14>
 
 
Pre-removal Operation
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator, Injector Lower Insulator and Common rail insulator Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Fuel Line Leak Check (Refer to )
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator, Injector Lower Insulator and Common rail insulator Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Removal steps
1.Engine control harness
2.Harness bracket assembly
3.Fuel pressure sensor connector
4.Fuel pressure relief control valve connector
>>A<<5.Eye bolt
>>A<<6.Fuel return gasket
>>A<<7.Fuel return pipe B
8.Fuel return line hose D
9.Fuel return line hose F
>>A<<10.Supply pump pipe
>>A<<11.Fuel injection pipe No.1
>>A<<12.Fuel injection pipe No.3
>>A<<13.Fuel injection pipe No.2
>>A<<14.Fuel injection pipe No.4
<<A>>>>A<<15.Common rail assembly
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> COMMON RAIL ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
caution
  • When operating, do not support the common rail assembly by holding the rail pressure sensor and the fuel pressure relief control valve at both ends.
  • Before the installation, make sure that there is no foreign object or rust to the thread and to the high-pressure pipe sheet surface.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< COMMON RAIL ASSEMBLY/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.4/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.2/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.3/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.1/SUPPLY PUMP PIPE/FUEL RETURN PIPE B/FUEL RETURN GASKET/EYE BOLT INSTALLATION
1. Install the common rail assembly to the cylinder head, and let the mounting bolt be seated (until the bolt slightly touches the common rail installation surface).
2.
caution
  • The removed fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe can be reassembled up to 5 times. To count the number of fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe reassembly, record it by adding the reassembly number of this time (once usually) to the previous number of reassembly written on the maintenance handbook. When the number of the previous reassembly reaches 5 or when the fuel injector assembly or common rail assembly is replaced, always use a new fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe. At that time, write "New (0 times)" in the maintenance handbook.
  • If a fuel leak is present in the fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe once, do not reuse it and replace with a new one.
  • If the common rail assembly is replaced, the contact surface (seal surface) between the fuel injection pipe or supply pump pipe and the common rail assembly is changed. So do not reuse the fuel injection pipe and fuel supply pump pipe and replace with a new one.
  • When reassembling the fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe, remove the foreign material attached on the sealing surface, and install it with the contacting point of the pipe aligned.
Align the fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe centre axis with the other side components (common rail assembly, fuel injector assembly and supply pump assembly) centre axis to install the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4 and supply pump pipe. Then, tighten the flare nut temporarily until the tip of pipe (seal surface) contacts with the other side components.
noteWhen the fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe are installed, tighten the flare nut while shaking the pipe lightly to align the centre axis of both components.
3. Temporarily install the fuel return pipe B to the rocker cover.
4. Temporarily install the supply pump pipe to the intake manifold.
5. Tighten the supply pump pipe mounting bolts, which are located on the intake manifold side of the temporarily installed supply pump pipe, to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 9.5 ± 2.5 N·m
6. Using special tool crowfoot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4 and supply pump pipe to the temporary tightening torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (18 ± 2) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 18 ± 2: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
7. Using special tool MB992211, tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 and supply pump pipe to the specified torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (35 ± 5) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 35 ± 5: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
8. Replace the fuel return gasket with a new one.
9. Install the fuel return pipe B to the common rail assembly and tighten the eye bolt to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 20 ± 2 N·m
10. Tighten the fuel return pipe B mounting bolt, which is located on the rocker cover side of the temporarily installed fuel return pipe B, to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 9.5 ± 2.5 N·m
11. Tighten the common rail assembly to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 25 ± 7 N·m
12. Check that no fuel is leaked from the pipe connection area and the fuel return gasket.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > COMMON RAIL > COMMON RAIL REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N15>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N15>
 
 
Pre-removal Operation
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator, Injector Lower Insulator and Common rail insulator Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Post-installation Operation
  • Fuel Line Leak Check (Refer to )
  • Engine Cover, Injector Upper Insulator, Injector Lower Insulator and Common rail insulator Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Removal steps
1.Engine control harness
2.Harness bracket assembly
3.Fuel pressure sensor connector
4.Gasket
5.Fuel return pipe B
6.Fuel return line hose D connection
7.Fuel return line hose F connection
>>A<<8.Supply pump pipe
>>A<<9.Fuel injection pipe No.1
>>A<<10.Fuel injection pipe No.3
>>A<<11.Fuel injection pipe No.2
>>A<<12.Fuel injection pipe No.4
<<A>>>>A<<13.Common rail assembly
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> COMMON RAIL ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
caution
  • When operating, do not support the common rail assembly by holding the rail pressure limiter and the pressure sensor at both ends.
  • Before the installation, make sure that there is no foreign object or rust to the thread and to the high-pressure pipe sheet surface.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< COMMON RAIL ASSEMBLY/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.4/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.2/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.3/FUEL INJECTION PIPE NO.1/SUPPLY PUMP PIPE INSTALLATION
1. Install the common rail assembly to the cylinder head, and let the mounting bolt be seated. (until the bolt slightly touches the common rail installation surface)
2.
caution
  • The removed fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe can be reassembled up to five times. To count the number of fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe reassembly, record it by adding the reassembly number of this time (once usually) to the previous number of reassembly written on the maintenance handbook. When the number of the previous reassembly reaches 5 or when the fuel injector assembly or common rail assembly is replaced, always use a new fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe. At that time, write "New (0 times)" in the maintenance handbook.
  • If a fuel leak is present in the fuel injection pipe and fuel injection pipe set once, do not reuse it and replace with a new one.
  • If the fuel injector assembly, common rail assembly or supply pump assembly is replaced, the contact surface (seal surface) between the fuel injection pipe and fuel injection pipe set, and the other side component is changed, do not reuse the fuel injection pipe and fuel supply pump pipe and replace with a new one.
  • When reassembling the fuel injection pipe and supply pump pipe, remove the foreign material attached on the sealing surface, and install it with the contacting point of the pipe aligned.
Align the fuel injection pipe centre axis with the other side components (common rail assembly, fuel injector assembly and supply pump assembly) centre axis to install the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4. Then, tighten the flare nut temporarily until the tip of pipe (seal surface) contacts with the other side components.
noteWhen the fuel injection pipe is installed, tighten the flare nut while shaking the pipe lightly to align the centre axis of both components.
3. Using the special tool crowfoot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No.1 to No.4 and supply pump pipe to the temporary tightening torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (18 ± 2) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 18 ± 2: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
4. Using the special tool MB992211, tighten the common rail assembly side of the fuel injection pipe No. 1 to No. 4 and supply pump pipe to the specified torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (35 ± 5) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 35 ± 5: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
5. Tighten the common rail assembly to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 25 ± 7 N·m
6. Check that no fuel is leaked from the fuel injection pipe connection area and the gasket.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > SUPPLY PUMP > SUPPLY PUMP REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
caution
  • To remove and install the supply pump, be careful not to damage the inside diameter of the pump engagement hole on the cylinder block.
  • When the supply pump is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
  • When the supply pump is replaced, perform the supply pump correction learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Throttle Body Assembly Removal (Refer to ).
  • Harness bracket Removal (Refer to ). <4N14>
  • Harness bracket Removal (Refer to ). <4N15>
  • EGR Cooler Removal (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • EGR Cooler Removal (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N15> ). <4N15>
  • Starter Assembly Removal (Refer to GROUP 16 - Starting System, Starter Assembly ).
  • Engine Oil Level Gauge Guide Removal (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • Engine Oil Level Gauge Guide Removal (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N15> ). <4N15>
  • Vacuum Pump Assembly Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N14>) <4N14>.
  • Vacuum Pump Assembly Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N15>) <4N15>.
  • Oil Pipe Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N14>) <4N14>.
  • Oil Pipe Removal (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N15>) <4N15>.
Post-installation Operation
  • Oil Pipe Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N15>) <4N15>.
  • Oil Pipe Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N14>) <4N14>.
  • Vacuum Pump Assembly Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N15>) <4N15>.
  • Vacuum Pump Assembly Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Vacuum Pump <4N14>) <4N14>.
  • Engine Oil Level Gauge Guide Installation (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N15> ). <4N15>
  • Engine Oil Level Gauge Guide Installation (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • Starter Assembly Installation (Refer to GROUP 16 - Starting System, Starter Assembly ).
  • EGR Cooler Installation (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N15> ). <4N15>
  • EGR Cooler Installation (Refer to GROUP 17 - Emission Control <DIESEL>, EGR Valve and EGR Cooler <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • Harness bracket Installation (Refer to ). <4N15>
  • Harness bracket Installation (Refer to ). <4N14>
  • Throttle Body Assembly Installation (Refer to ).
  • Fuel Line Leak Check (Refer to ).
Removal steps
•Water hose H connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe <4N14> ). <4N14>
•Water hose K connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe <4N14> ). <4N14>
•Water hose I connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe <4N14> ). <4N14>
•Water hose H connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe <4N15> ). <4N15>
•Water hose I connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe <4N15> ). <4N15>
1.Fuel hose D connection
2.Fuel inlet pipe assembly
3.Fuel inlet hose
4.Fuel return hose connection
5.Fuel return pipe assembly A
6.Fuel return hose E
7.Fuel return hose F
>>B<<8.Supply pump pipe
<<A>>>>A<<9.Supply pump mounting bolt
<<B>>>>A<<10.Supply pump assembly
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINTS
 
 
<<A>> SUPPLY PUMP MOUNTING BOLT REMOVAL
1. Working through the vacuum pump opening on the timing chain case, align the slit in the supply pump gear with the oil channel hole in the timing chain case.
2. Remove the supply pump mounting bolts.
 

 
 
<<B>> SUPPLY PUMP ASSEMBLY REMOVAL
When you pull out the supply pump gear from the supply pump assembly, loosen the supply pump gear mounting nut according to the procedure below in advance.
1. Use the following special tools to support the crankshaft pulley.
  • Front hub and flange yoke holder (MB990767)
  • Pin (MD998719)
2. Loosen the supply pump gear mounting nut.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINTS
 
 
>>A<< SUPPLY PUMP ASSEMBLY / SUPPLY PUMP MOUNTING BOLT INSTALLATION
1. Position the key slit on the supply pump gear as shown.
2. Remove all the residual sealant from the threaded hole in the cylinder block.
When the supply pump mounting bolt is reused, carefully remove the residual sealant from the bolt thread.
3. When the supply pump mounting bolt is reused, apply the sealant as shown.
Specified sealant: ThreeBond 2403 or equivalent
4. Insert the supply pump assembly through the vacuum pump opening in the timing chain case so that the slit on the supply pump gear is aligned with the oil channel hole on the timing chain case.
5. Tighten the supply pump mounting bolts to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 25 ± 7 N·m
6. If the supply pump gear mounting nut is loosened, use the same special tools as during removal to tighten the supply pump gear mounting nut to the specified torque.
  • Front hub and flange yoke holder (MB990767)
  • Pin (MD998719)
Tightening torque: 83 ± 5 N·m
 
 
 
>>B<< SUPPLY PUMP PIPE INSTALLATION
1.
caution
  • The removed supply pump pipe can be reassembled up to five times. To count the number of supply pump pipe reassembly, record it by adding the reassembly number of this time (once usually) to the previous number of reassembly written on the maintenance handbook. When the number of the previous reassembly reaches 5 or when the supply pump assembly or common rail assembly is replaced, always use a new supply pump pipe. At that time, write "New (0 times)" in the maintenance handbook.
  • If a fuel leak is present in the supply pump pipe and supply pump pipe set once, do not reuse it and replace with a new one.
  • If the supply pump assembly, common rail assembly is replaced, the contact surface (seal surface) between the supply pump pipe and supply pump pipe set, and the other side component is changed, do not reuse the supply pump pipe and replace with a new one.
  • When reassembling the supply pump pipe, remove the foreign material attached on the sealing surface, and install it with the contacting point of the pipe aligned.
Align the supply pump pipe centre axis with the other side components (common rail assembly and supply pump assembly) centre axis to install the supply pump pipe. Then, tighten the flare nut temporarily until the tip of pipe (seal surface) contacts with the other side components.
noteWhen the supply pump pipe is installed, tighten the flare nut while shaking the pipe lightly to align the centre axis of both components.
2. Using the special tool fuel injector pipe wrench (MB992188) or equivalent tool, tighten the supply pump side of the supply pump pipe to the temporary tightening torque.
Tightening torque: 18 ± 2 N·m
3. Using the special tool crowfoot wrench (MB992211), tighten the common rail assembly side of the supply pump pipe to the temporary tightening torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (18 ± 2) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 18 ± 2: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
4. Using the special tool MB992188 or equivalent tool, tighten the supply pump side of the supply pump pipe to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 35 ± 5 N·m
5. Using the special tool MB992211, tighten the common rail assembly side of the supply pump pipe to the specified torque calculated by the following formula.
Tightening torque: (35 ± 5) × {L ÷ (L + 25)} N·m
  • 35 ± 5: Tightening torque of the fuel injection pipe (unit: N·m)
  • L: Distance between the centre of a torque wrench drive and of its handle (unit: mm)
  • 25: Length of pitch for special tool between holes (unit: mm)
6. Check that no fuel is leaked from the supply pump pipe connection area.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > SUPPLY PUMP > SUPPLY PUMP DISASSEMBLY AND ASSEMBLY
DISASSEMBLY AND ASSEMBLY
 
 
Disassembly steps
<<A>>1.Supply pump gear
2.Sleeve
>>A<<3.O-ring
4.O-ring
5.Supply pump
 
 
DISASSEMBLY SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> SUPPLY PUMP GEAR REMOVAL
Use the following special tools and a press to pull out the supply pump gear.
  • Oil seal installer (MB991199)
  • Remover (MD998801)
 
 
 
 
REASSEMBLY SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< O-RING INSTALLATION
Apply engine oil to the O-ring.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > SUCTION CONTROL VALVE > SUCTION CONTROL VALVE REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
caution
  • Unless replaced, do not remove the suction control valve.
  • When the Suction control valve is replaced, use the M.U.T.-III to initialise the learning value (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, Initialisation Procedure for Learning Value in Common Rail Engine ).
  • When the Suction control valve is replaced, perform the supply pump correction learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, What the Common Rail Engine Learns ).
Pre-removal Operation
  • Battery Tray Removal (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery ).
  • Throttle Body Assembly Removal (Refer to ).
  • Oil Level Gauge Guide Removal (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • Oil Level Gauge Guide Removal (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N15> ). <4N15>
Post-installation Operation
  • Oil Level Gauge Guide Installation (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N15> ). <4N15>
  • Oil Level Gauge Guide Installation (Refer to GROUP 15 - Inlet Manifold <4N14> ). <4N14>
  • Throttle Body Assembly Installation (Refer to ).
  • Battery Tray Installation (Refer to GROUP 54A - Battery ).
Removal steps
•Water hose I connection (Refer to GROUP 12 - Engine Oil Cooler <4N14> ). <4N14>
•Water hose A connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe Cooler <4N14> ). <4N14>
•Water hose I connection (Refer to GROUP 12 - Engine Oil Cooler <4N15> ). <4N15>
•Water hose A connection (Refer to GROUP 14 - Water Hose and Water Pipe Cooler <4N15> ). <4N15>
<<A>>>>A<<1.Suction control valve kit
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> SUCTION CONTROL VALVE KIT REMOVAL.
1. Clean the area around the suction control valve with a cleaner, etc.
2.
cautionPay attention not to let foreign materials get into the supply pump during and after the suction control valve removal.
Loosen the suction control valve mounting bolts, and remove the suction control valve from the supply pump.
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< SUCTION CONTROL VALVE KIT INSTALLATION
1.
caution
  • Pay attention not to let the suction control valve be contaminated with foreign material when installing it.
  • Pay attention not to let foreign materials get into the supply pump during the suction control valve installation.
Apply a drop of new engine oil to the O-ring in the supply pump groove, and insert the suction control valve by hands until it contacts with the supply pump. When inserting the suction control valve, make sure that the suction control valve connector is in the direction shown in the figure.
2.
cautionTighten the 2 suction control valve mounting bolts evenly.
Tighten the suction control valve mounting bolts to the specified torque.
Tightening torque: 8.9 ± 1.9 N·m
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > THROTTLE BODY ASSEMBLY > THROTTLE BODY ASSEMBLY REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
Pre-removal and Post-installation Operation
  • Engine Cover Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly ).
Removal steps
1.Intercooler outlet air hose D connection
2.Throttle body connector
3.Throttle body assembly
>>A<<4.Throttle body gasket
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINT
 
 
>>A<< THROTTLE BODY GASKET INSTALLATION
Install the throttle body gasket as its projection is in the direction shown.
 
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > CAMSHAFT POSITION SENSOR AND CRANK ANGLE SENSOR > CAMSHAFT POSITION SENSOR AND CRANK ANGLE SENSOR REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION
 
 
<CAMSHAFT POSITION SENSOR>
Removal steps
•Engine cover (Refer to GROUP 11A - Engine Assembly )
1.Camshaft position sensor connector
2.Camshaft position sensor
3.O-ring

<CRANK ANGLE SENSOR>
Removal steps
•Under Cover (Refer to GROUP 51 - Under Cover )
•Front propeller shaft connection (Refer to GROUP 26 - Differential Carrier and Free Wheeling Clutch <4WD>). <4WD>
<<A>>1.Crank angle sensor and crank angle sensor connector
2.Crank angle sensor connector
3.Crank angle sensor
4.O-ring
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> CRANK ANGLE SENSOR AND CRANK ANGLE SENSOR CONNECTOR REMOVAL
1. Remove the crank angle sensor with the crank angle sensor connector connected.
2. Disconnect the connector.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ENGINE-ECU > ENGINE-ECU REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N14>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N14>
 
 
caution
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, another ECU related to KOS system should not replaced together. Always replace the ECU by ones when the multiple ECU is replaced, and then replace the next ECU after registering the necessary IDs by using M.U.T.-III.
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, coding must be performed.
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, using M.U.T.-III to write the chassis number (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions before Service, How to Perform Chassis Number Writing).
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, register the injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns).
Pre-removal and Post-installation Operation
  • Cowl Side Trim (RH) Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 52A - Trims, Interior Trim ).
  • Clearance Warning Control Unit and bracket Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 54A - Clearance Warning Control Unit ). <Vehicles with Corner Sensor System>
Removal steps
>>C<<•Initialisation operation <only at installation>
<<A>>>>B<<1.Break-off bolt <Vehicles without Corner Sensor System>
2.Control unit bracket <Vehicles without Corner Sensor System>
<<B>>>>A<<1.Engine-ECU connectors
2.ECU lower bracket
3.Engine-ECU
4.ECU upper bracket
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINTS
 
 
<<A>> BREAK-OFF BOLT REMOVAL
1. <When using reverse screw tap>
(1) Use a drill to make a hole just deeply enough for the tap to stand on the break-off.
(2) Remove the break-off with a reverse screw tap.
2. <When using the flat-tipped screwdriver>
(1) Apply force towards the direction to loose the break-off bolt by a flat-tipped screwdriver.
(2) Remove the break-off bolt.
 

 
 
<<B>> ENGINE-ECU CONNECTOR DISCONNECTION
cautionBe sure to press the connector cover when turning the lock lever, or the connector may be damaged.
noteIf the connector cover should come off, engage the lock lever gear with the connector gear. Then, install the connector cover to the connector. Press the lock button to unlock the lock lever. While pressing the connector cover against the connector, turn the lock lever to the vertical position. Then, disconnect the connector from the engine-ECU.
Press the lock button to unlock the lock lever. While pressing the connector cover against the engine-ECU, turn the lock lever to the vertical position. Then, disconnect the connector from the engine-ECU.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINTS
 
 
>>A<< ENGINE-ECU CONNECTOR CONNECTION
1.
cautionWhen inserting the connector to the engine-ECU, be careful not to apply force in the directions other than the inserting direction.
Move the lock lever of the connector to the unlock status, and then install the connector to the engine-ECU. Insert the connector as far as it goes.
2.
cautionMake sure that the connector is inserted sufficiently before locking it, or the lock lever may be damaged.
While pressing the connector toward the engine-ECU side, turn the lock lever to lock the connector.
 
 
 
>>B<< BREAK-OFF BOLT INSTALLATION
Tighten the break-off bolt until its head is broken off.
 
 
>>C<< INITIALISATION OPERATION
Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position and then to "LOCK" (OFF) position and hold it for at least 10 seconds.
 
13 -FUEL > 13A-DIESEL FUEL > ENGINE-ECU > ENGINE-ECU REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION<4N15>
REMOVAL AND INSTALLATION <4N15>
 
 
caution
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, another ECU related to KOS system should not replaced together. Always replace the ECU by ones when the multiple ECU is replaced, and then replace the next ECU after registering the necessary IDs by using M.U.T.-III.
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, coding must be performed.
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, using M.U.T.-III to write the chassis number. (Refer to GROUP 00, Precautions before Service - How to Perform Chassis Number Writing .)
  • When the engine-ECU is replaced, register the injector identification code and perform the small injection quantity learning (Refer to GROUP 00 - Precautions Before Service, What The Common Rail Engine Learns ).
Pre-removal and Post-installation Operation
  • Cowl Side Trim (RH) Removal and Installation (Refer to GROUP 52A - Trims, Interior Trim ).
Removal steps
>>B<<•Initialisation operation <only at installation>
<<A>>>>A<<1.Engine-ECU connectors
2.ECU lower bracket
3.Engine-ECU
4.ECU upper bracket
 
 
REMOVAL SERVICE POINT
 
 
<<A>> ENGINE-ECU CONNECTOR DISCONNECTION
cautionBe sure to press the connector cover when turning the lock lever, or the connector may be damaged.
noteIf the connector cover should come off, engage the lock lever gear with the connector gear. Then, install the connector cover to the connector. Press the lock button to unlock the lock lever. While pressing the connector cover against the connector, turn the lock lever to the vertical position. Then, disconnect the connector from the engine-ECU.
Press the lock button to unlock the lock lever. While pressing the connector cover against the engine-ECU, turn the lock lever to the vertical position. Then, disconnect the connector from the engine-ECU.
 
 
 
 
INSTALLATION SERVICE POINTS
 
 
>>A<< ENGINE-ECU CONNECTOR CONNECTION
1.
cautionWhen inserting the connector to the engine-ECU, be careful not to apply force in the directions other than the inserting direction.
Move the lock lever of the connector to the unlock status, and then install the connector to the engine-ECU. Insert the connector as far as it goes.
2.
cautionMake sure that the connector is inserted sufficiently before locking it, or the lock lever may be damaged.
While pressing the connector toward the engine-ECU side, turn the lock lever to lock the connector.
 
 
 
>>B<< INITIALISATION OPERATION
Turn the ignition switch to the "ON" position and then to "LOCK" (OFF) position and hold it for at least 10 seconds.
